results.description:
The annual Mission Hill Community Health Fair on Saturday,
April 9, from 11 am to 3 pm, needs staffers for the Fair Foods TABLE because Fair Foods is so busy with their own several bagging and distribution operations at other sites.

What will be involved is unloading produce from a truck and bagging 4 items rather than 7-10 items in the bags.

Instead of taking cash, we'll be handing out FREE bags and telling people about the 6 Fair Foods locations in and around Mission Hill.

So we want volunteers who are succinct, articulate, healthy and presentable, and hard-working - able to project a 'let's get healthy' image for Fair Foods and for the event host, Mission Hill Health Movement.

Mission Hill residents are a diverse crowd over over 15,000, but about 1/3 of those residents are undergraduates and others related to the college, professional school, and institutional learning environments surrounding the Mission Hill neighborhood of Roxbury.
results.name: Fair Foods TABLE at Mission Hill Community Health Fair

results.description:
Join neighbors and friends at the Boston Nature Center in Mattapan for this free workshop/workday on both Saturday and Sunday, April 9th and 10th, between 10am and 3pm. 

Drop in for an hour or bring a lunch and stay for the day, there will be plenty of good ole' gardening to do as we kick off the snow and bring the warmth of good friends and good work. Our goals are to sheet mulch 4,000sq ft and top off our existing hugelkultur beds (new constructions come Sunday 4/24). Broadforks will be out in force as will our cardboard crew and everything in between, so there will be fun work for all ages and experience levels.

Snacks and water will be provided, so bring a water bottle and some good gardening clothes.

Hope to see you out there!
results.name: Boston Food Forest Coalition: Sheet Mulching & Hugelkultur

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
5th Annual Get Growing Festival brings together gardeners, would-be gardeners, and community members of all ages. Activities for everybody: start seeds, make a seed ball (to toss!), build a raised bed or rain barrel. Meet a chicken. Get tips on making compost, keeping bees, growing a lot in a small space, IDing edible weeds, protecting the planet. Connect with fun projects: harvest community fruit, share a yard, pull invasive weeds, glean edibles for hunger relief. And new this year: swaps! Bring plants, seeds, and garden/cooking books you don’t want and take away something new.

5th Annual Get Growing Festival
Saturday, April 9
10am to 2pm
Upstairs from the winter farmers’ market, 5 Callender Street (near Central Square), Cambridge

For more info: https://www.facebook.com/events/1154586774554042/
results.name: Cambridge's 5th Annual Get Growing Festival

results.description:
Volunteer @FPR in John Eliot Square, Roxbury for $2 Bag of Vegetables
or get a $2 Bag for yourself just by showing up as 'an interested customer'

Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org) delivers fresh (rescued) produce to about 60+ sites (only some are made public and publicized), and they hope to add MORE sites.  http://FairFoods.org/dollarbag.html

Usually (but not always), each site is hosted by a local organization (mostly nonprofits, but some are for-profit residences).

Each site needs unpaid volunteers to help
(a) unload the truck(s),
(b) set up the tables and produce (in order by weight, from heavy to light), and
(c) bag the produce into standard bags, which each sites 'neighbors' will come by (during the 'open' period) and take for $2/bag.

Most (but not all) sites get freshly-baked bread (baked fresh that morning).

Volunteers get to take home one or two (or more) bags of produce for themselves and 1-2 loaves of bread, also - because they volunteered.

To volunteer, in-mail the Meetup event host and say specifically which site and which date and time interests you (so that you can be registered in advance as a volunteer). In that in-mail, please provide your ACTUAL e-mail address, real full name, and phone number.

Please bring lots and lots of extra used but clean and reusable plastic bags for the bagging.


Bring with you some means for transporting home with you your own 'comped' produce (backpack/s, cloth shopping bag/s, duffel bag/s).
results.name: Volunteer @FPR for $2 Bag of Vegetables - or get a $2 Bag for Yourself

results.description:
Our conversational groups are
tabling at The Mission Hill Health Fair - 
https://www.facebook.com/events/1701939220093758/ - on Saturday in a specifically Chinese/Asian ‘section’ of several exhibitors and participants.  

This special section was requested by several of the tablers who already know one another.

http://www.meetup.com/bostonchina/events/230102748/

1. Asian Women for Health (you share interests already) – organized and led by Chien-Chi Huang, MBA, a cancer survivor who has heroically managed to bring together much of Boston’s public health infrastructure and to focus their energies broadly upon the needs of Asian women 
2. Phoenix Rising Toishonese-speaking dance troupe – founded and led by a retired psychology professor from People’s Republic of China (and also a Mandarin speaker), Donghui ‘Sophia’ Deng 
3. Asian American Civic Association – Ms. Yi Yi Lu – who presents a broad array of social services to Asian Americans, which could be a good networking contact for Ms. Chen and many others in your group. 
4. Dr. May Liu (PhD) and her sister, Dr. Lily Liu (MD, PhD) from Harvard Medical School – on low glycemic eating for general health, weight maintenance, and glucose control (reportedly a highly prevalent medical condition among many Chinese). They’re from PRC. 
5. Our groups - Thuy and other tablers from 
(a) the weekly Mandarin-English Tuesday evening chat group at Harvard Chan School and 
(b) the weekly Cantonese-English Friday evening chat group at Boston Huntington Avenue YMCA 
6. There may have others

The Mission Hill Health Fair event’s Facebook page: 
https://www.facebook.com/events/1701939220093758/

Thuy is organizing the table at the annual Mission Hill Health Fair - a.k.a. Mission Hill Community Health, Wellness, and Fitness Fair, and she invites everyone else in this group to stop in briefly to visit, support her, to sit with her, to enjoy the fair and the Asian section of exhbitors, and to get some free food and maybe even to bounce in the Bounce House, participate in the raffles, and learn about all kinds of wonderful resources available in this Mission Hill neighborhood.

The tablers need to be AT the Sheehy Park, 1545 Tremont Street, Mission Hill 02120 by 10 am and stay UNTIL 3 pm.

OUR two groups - Mandarin-English and Cantonese-English - have something to offer in terms of healthful living, and scientific, clinical, and research expertise related to health, AND being there is educational for us (and a good social event) - in general, and among Chinese tablers, AND we could recruit others to attend the Tuesday and Friday evening chat groups.

We're a resource IN the Longwood MEDICAL Area (LMA) on the edge of Mission Hill (the City of Boston considers LMA to be PART of Mission Hill).
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Come by and support Thuy at our groups' table - and get to know the other Asian groups that are networking together.
results.name: Participate in the Chinese Tables section at Mission Hill Health Fair

results.description:
Walk for[masked] minutes, then lunch at the Colonial Inn, Concord.

Great Meadows is located just 20 miles west of Boston. The refuge was established in 1947 to provide nesting, resting, and feeding habitat for migratory birds. Roughly 85 percent of the refuge's 3,600 acres is comprised of valuable freshwater wetlands stretching along 12 miles of the Concord and Sudbury Rivers. Well known for its birdwatching opportunities, the public can also enjoy a variety of other wildlife-dependent recreational activities while visiting the refuge.

The draining of each pool is variably timed to benefit different groups of migrating birds. One pool is drained earlier in the season to encourage the growth of native forage plants that benefit fall-migrating waterfowl. The other pool is drained later in the summer to expose the invertebrate-rich mud flats that provide food for wading birds such as herons and egrets. Both pools are flooded in the fall and remain inundated until the following spring and summer.


No dogs allowed.  It is a flat path.  We will walk for 2 to 2 1/2 hours.  Then if anyone wants to travel on another path, that is an option.
results.how_to_find_us: meet in the parking lot, please carpool if you can

results.description:
Join me for a spring hike (at least I think it's spring) around the Cedar Hill- Crane Swamp conservation area in Marlborough. I don't know the exact trail conditions, but given the crazy weather we could run into anything. Ice, snow and mud are all possibilities, please be prepared. The hike will last for about two hours

http://www.sudburyvalleytrustees.org/sites/default/files/property/map/craneswamp.pdf


Please bring water.

Winter boots or hiking boots - no sneakers.

Adults only

Registered members only - no guests.

No dogs allowed on the hike.

DIRECTIONS


Cedar Hill, Marlborough/Northborough

For the north entrance, take Route 495 to exit 23C (Simarano Drive exit). Continue to the
lights at the end of the exit ramp. Take a left
at the lights onto Simarano Drive. Continue to another set of lights and take a right onto Cedar Hill Street. Parking for the reservation is at the Scholastic Book Fairs at 360 Cedar Hill Street. The entrance will be on your left across from Forest Street. There is ample parking, labeled with SVT signs, immediately on your right. A trail easement, marked by posts and SVT markers leads around the wetlands and to a kiosk behind Scholastic Book Fairs.

Lunch

Tavern on the Square

318 Main St, Northborough

http://taverninthesquare.com/northborough/info

Please Read The Fine Print:


Duration: Approximately 2 hours for the hike. However, any time estimate given is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. I am not responsible for getting you back in time for later in the day plans. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there, then please don't sign up.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain, snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots or sneakers, bug spray, snacks and any personal medicines. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free, and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader you will be very disappointed. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.


By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.
results.how_to_find_us: I will be waiting near the information kiosk.
results.name: Is it really Spring? Hike & Lunch

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Mar 5, 12, 19, Apr 2, 9 and 16.  There is no class on the weekend of Mar 26) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

Enjoy this unique exercise of simulated laughter combined with gentle breathing that brings more oxygen to the body's cells. This oxygen boost gives enhanced vitality, energy and a feeling of real well-being.

Please bring your water bottle because laughing is dehydrating. Led by Certified Laughter Yoga Teachers, Linda and Bill Hamaker. www.letslaughtoday.com If you have any questions, just call them at[masked] or e-mail [masked]. PLEASE BRING A CANNED GOOD FOR THE SHARON FOOD PANTRY.

The front page of the March 15, 2013 Sharon Advocate (weekly newspaper) has this excellent article:  http://www.wickedlocal.com/sharon/features/x846070314/Yoga-laughter-a-lot-of-fun-in-Sharon?img=1#axzz2NcOfal37 and also this photo gallery on-line: http://www.wickedlocal.com/sharon/photos/x846070312/Photo-gallery-Laughter-yoga

Descriptions:

Classes and Worshops


11:00-12:00 - Walk it Out : The Walk lets us get in close, sway & stroll, bop & strut. This urban ballroom dance is easy, relaxed, and all about subtle movements to some of the best slow jams ever recorded. 


12:10-1:10 - Don't Mess with Texas: Despite the name both the Blues dance the Texas Shuffle and it's soulful cousin the Texas Hop hail from California. This class will focus on open position movement with some of fanciest footwork on the dance floor. 


1:10-2:10 - LUNCH


2:10-3:10 - Intro to Chicago Style Steppin': The Original Steppers of Boston will offer an introduction to Chicago Style Steppin' Workshop featuring " lead" and "follow" basic foot patterns, turns and combinations.

West Coast Swing dancers, Steppers, and Blues dancers have in common and how we can best work together to create a unique dance based on shared principles of movement and common patterns.

This April's Vegan Meetup/Tweetup is the Mission Hill Community Health Fair at Sheehy Park at 1545 Tremont Street, Mission Hill, Roxbury.

Fair Foods needs volunteers to help us bag and distribute produce at the health fair on 4/9.
Could you do that, since we are taking the entire vegan meetup to the health fair?

Please join us there, and consider volunteering for one of the advocacy organizations: Fair Foods (whose mission is getting produce out to people in mixed bags, for $2/bag) or Food Not Bombs. (feeding people vegan vegetarian food for free - typically at protests - make nonviolent vegan meals, not war - "be a public servant" with Food Not Bombs).

People of all ages, backgrounds, metaphysical beliefs, levels of accomplishment, and other differences who believe in what we are doing in practicing veganism and vegan diets - and in its value and importance - are welcome to join us. 

Boston Vegan Tweetup/Meetup 

http://Vegan.Meetup.com/23/

results.description:
It's a short ten-minute walk from the parking lot to the Mt. Hood Tower (about .3 miles). The tower offers views of the Boston skyline and some of the coast (a bit of the beach in the distance). Then we walk back to the cars. That whole thing takes about 1/2 hr - 45 minutes.
There are some stone steps to get to the tower and the tower itself has 56 steps on a spiral staircase inside....it's worth it when you get to the top! Google it to see some pretty pictures....

Then we can check out the Mt. Hood Clubhouse (maybe it will be open for a drink...) and walk around the golf course area. Watch out for stray golf balls and cute guys!

THEN, those that want to walk more, can walk 1.5 miles to downtown Melrose for coffee and/or dessert at one of our fine restaurants and bistros.
Then we walk back 1.5 miles to Mt. Hood to get our cars. If anyone wanted to drive downtown, that's fine too, or skip that part all together. I just know that I am ready for some outdoor walking and would love the company!!!!
results.name: Walk Mt. Hood Tower/Downtown Melrose: Sat 4/9 11:00 am

results.description:
Note to ALL:  Looking forward to meeting everybody today!

Possible changes:  In the event, the playing field is not available for whatever the reason the backup plan will be to go to Hopkinton State Park on Rt. 85 and meet at parking lot D, just past the boat rental area.

DINNER - Anyone interested in going out to dinner afterwards?

Have questions? Or want my contact information (cell phone number just in case you can't find our group, email request to: [masked] and add CONTACT INFO REQUEST in the subject area of your email. Please provide yours so I know who I am communicating with. 

Be sure to read this complete announcement to answer questions or concerns.

The hike around the Ashland Reservoir is 3.2 miles and will take at least a couple of hours at a good pace. You should be in reasonably good shape to do this walk.  Below is link to map of Ashland State Park.


http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/ashland.pdf


This is the entrance sign that is located on Rt. 135 in Ashland
162 W Union St Ashland, Massachusetts 01721


At present there are no public restrooms open.


Pictures below show the exposed tree roots and rocks on the trail. Recommend wearing hiking shoes with good traction.


Lets meet at the parking lot near the entrance to Ashland State Park as close as possible to the Robert Hill Pavilion at 12:45 - 1 PM.  Shown below.

Please DON't be late.  

We'll begin the day with walk around the Ashland Reservoir Trail loop that's 3.2 miles.

Then we'll meet back at the field next to the Robert Hill Pavilion (probably around 2:30 PM and let the fun begin with these exciting new outdoor yard games!  The rain or snow date will be the following Saturday. 

In the event, the playing field is not available for whatever the reason the backup plan will be to go to Hopkinton State Park on Rt. 85 and meet at parking lot D, just past the boat rental area.


Have you ever play Kubb?

Kubb is a lawn game where the object is to knock over wooden blocks by throwing wooden sticks at them. Kubb can be simply described as a combination of bowling and horseshoes. The ultimate object of the game is to knock the "king" over, before the opponent does.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liMZ-dFMJSc

How about Cornhole?

Scoring is simple. After all bags have been thrown, a bag remaining on the board is worth 1 point. A bag that went in the hole is worth 3 points. Add up how many points you earned and compare them to your opponents. Equal points cancel each other out so that only one team can score per round. For example, if you scored 5 points and your opponent scored 3, you will add 2 points to your overall score and your team will throw first in the next round. If you scored 6 points and your opponent scored 6 as well, there will be no points awarded and whoever threw first in the last round will throw first again. A game is won when a team reaches 21 points with a lead of 2 or more points. The first team to win 2 games wins the match.

Hopefully there will be field space to be a kids again and play some Kickball!

Questions or want my contact information (cell phone number in case you can't find our group email: [masked]  Let's have some fun and be on the lookout for the next FWF event coming soon!

Organizer assumes no liability either before, during, or after this event.
results.name: FWF - Fun With Friends - Ashland State Park - Hike & Outdoor Games

results.description:
This sacred circle's intention is to transform victimhood (where we resonant with "life happens to us") to resonance with taking personal responsibility and creating our lives.

All humans have buried emotions, beliefs, programs etc. that are still very much alive in our bodies.  When we acknowledge them and validate them, we give these emotions/beliefs space to transform into something that serves us.  We will be using essential oils, EFT (tapping/emotional freedom technique) and an emotional release process which involves essential oils, the Chinese meridians and communication with our whole body wisdom.  

There is no need to understand any of the above -- only the intention to transform your frequency and resonance to what serves you.

Exchange is $35.  

You can pay cash at the door or reserve your space via credit card at www.enhanceyourfrequency.com/purchase-healing-sessions

Feel free to email me with any questions!

Tara
results.how_to_find_us: On the corner of Pelham Rd and Eliot Rd (brown house)
results.name: Transforming Victimhood to Empowerment Circle

results.description:
This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops. Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python (including scipy, numpy, and matlplotlib packages) installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. If you are new to Python and don't have an environment like Spyder or PyCharm already set up, please use IPython Notebook (http://ipython.org/notebook.html).

The focus of this session will be making music with Python. Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover how computers play music files, how we can create our own digital music, how we can use the computer to distort existing music in cool ways, and ultimately how to make our own music using Python. Under the broader umbrella of digital signal processing, we can also explore topics from speech recognition to medical imaging.

When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

If possible, please email [masked]a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

Spring session dates (we will open signups for the later dates a week in advance):

• 4/9

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

results.description:
This is week 1 of our Intermediate track: web development (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript if we have the time/interest)

This course will be progressive, so if you can’t make all 4 weeks, it could be tough to catch up (depending on your kids’ previous experience with these languages). When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

Prerequisites: Kids should have completed a Scratch (or Scratch equivalent) programming course, and be comfortable with basic programming concepts. This course assumes no prior knowledge of HTML or CSS.

What to bring: Laptop (+ charger) with a text editor for coding installed. I recommend Sublime Text 3 (it’s free to try indefinitely). Notepad++ is another good option. Another alternative (though not recommended, because you won’t be able to follow along exactly with the lesson) is to use a browser-based web editor, like codepen.io--this is an option for anyone who only has a Chromebook available.

Location: We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in Seaport. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be some street parking (bring quarters) as well as a few lots in the area. The nearest T stop is South Station.

Note: We're always looking for mentors, and also non-technical volunteers. If you’re interested in helping out, let us know at [masked], or sign up for the Mentor Mailing List.

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 9, 1:30-4pm)

We're doing a new 4-week endurance series! All levels are welcome, and you don't need to be able to make it every week.


The 4 weeks will help you keep swimming for longer without getting as tired, whether you're training for a triathlon coming up or just working on your swimming. We'll talk about and practice pacing yourself. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

results.description:
Saturday Matinee "Unfolding Beauty"  QWOC Cinema Pt. II 


An event dedicated to LGBTQ women of color in film. 

In commemoration and partnership with Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project ( QWOCMAP )and the Boston LGBT Film Festival (Wicked Queer), the LOCS Collective presents  "Unfolding Beauty" a series of QWOC short films.

Free Community Event

Harvard Law School - Wasserstein Hall

3rd Floor - Room 3019

Cambridge, MA 02134

About "Unfolding Beauty" (series of film shorts): 

A genderqueer ugly duckling emerges from the shell of oppression and heartbreak into a sparkling fairytale SWANICORN full of hope. It’s back to basics in SEXUALITY 101: IDENTITY as two young women insolently define their own labels. The magnetic moments of BEING SEEN BEING HOME fully affirm a fat femme as the heavenly body that she is. A young woman courageously embraces her perceived flaws IN HER EYES.  The poetic affirmation of #BLACKWOMENSLIVESMATTER shows us how to transform systemic devaluation.  An offering under the SUNGAZE sparks renewal and growth.  A queer Black man on a spiritual journey discovers his path to being PROUD & FAITHFUL.  AU-KNAPPTURAL embraces the beauty that is bald heads and Black hair.  A new HER/CUT leads to an awkward encounter between old friends. A young queer Asian-American writes A LETTER TO MY FATHER within the space of their family restaurant. MAMITIS makes a long journey home after years as an immigrant. A bisexual transgender Asian woman celebrates JASMINE'S JUBILEE and life’s triumphs. Based on the Samoan word for love HIS VISION: PROJECT ALOFA embraces all without judgement. For a trio of queer friends, the expansive magnitude of FINDING EACH OTHER draws them into activist community.  An Afro-Latina queer couple explores DE COLORES, OUR LIVES at the intersection of cultural, sexual and racial identity.

The Short Films: 

Swanicorn by Jaq Nguyen Victor 
Sexuality 101: Identity by Victoria Estrada, Halle Johnson 
Being Seen Being Home by Lylliam Posadas 
In Her Eyes by Jordan Gash, Irene Tu 
#BlackWomensLivesMatter by Xhercis Méndez 
Sungaze by Shereen Choudhury 
Proud & Faithful by L'Oréal Patrice Jackson 
Au-Knapptural by Sonjhai Meggette 
Her/cut by Xiomara Benitez, Rebecca Leo 
A Letter to My Father by Karen Liu  
Mamitis by Sandra Ramirez 
Jasmine's Jubilee by Lynn T Sugihara 
His Vision: Project ALOFA by Jacqueline Case, Nicole Pote, Holly Riordan-Gonzales 
Finding Each Other by Shirley Hsin*I Liu 
De Colores, Our Lives by Edgardo Antonio Jr, Jovanka Beckles, Nicole Valentino  


For more information and  tickets, please visit </a>https://unfoldingbeautymatinee.eventbrite.com


POSTPONED: 1950s Hollywood Glamour Masquerade 


Event Sponsors include Harvard Law School LAMBDA, <a href="http://www.wickedqueer.org/">Boston LGBT Film Festival , District Hall, and Edge Media Network
results.how_to_find_us: 3rd Floor - Room 3019
results.name: Saturday Matinee "Unfolding Beauty" - Queer Women of Color Cinema Pt. II

results.description:
MIDNIGHT SPECIAL TICKETS - This showing will be in the 45 seat Screening Room.  It will definitely sell out.  Please get your tickets in advance

http://www.coolidge.org/sites/all/themes/contrib/coolidge_fusion/images/add-to-any-icon.jpghttp://www.coolidge.org/sites/default/files/images/banners/midnightspecial_banner.jpg?1457035785

Midnight SpecialOpens Friday, April 1NEW RELEASESBOX OFFICE BABIES</a><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8UU_CC81aGM">Watch Trailer1hr 51mins // directed by:Jeff Nichols // featuring:Adam Driver, Kirsten Dunst, Michael Shannonoverview

Writer/director Jeff Nichols proves again that he is one of the most compelling storytellers of our time with the sci-fi thriller Midnight Special. A provocative, genre-defying film as supernatural as it is intimately human, it follows a father, Roy (Michael Shannon), who goes on the run to protect his young son, Alton (Jaeden Lieberher), a boy with mysterious powers that even Roy himself cannot comprehend.

What starts as a race from religious extremists and local law enforcement quickly escalates to a nationwide manhunt involving the highest levels of the Federal Government. Risking everything, Roy is committed to helping Alton reach his ultimate purpose, whatever that might be and whatever it costs, in a story that takes audiences on a perilous journey from Texas to the Florida coast, while exploring the bonds of love and trust, and the nature of faith.

"Midnight Special's intriguing mysteries may not resolve themselves to every viewer's liking, but the journey is ambitious, entertaining, and terrifically acted."

"In his fourth feature, Midnight Special, Jeff Nichols pays transporting homage to the rich tradition, spanning the late 1970s through the mid-'80s, of intelligent sci-fi emotionally grounded in relatable human dynamics. There's an explicit nod, in particular, to John Carpenter'sStarman, echoed even in the enveloping mood of David Wingo's driving electronic score. But this suspenseful, beautifully acted supernatural thriller is also very much of a piece with Nichols' overarching thematic concerns and stylistic approach" - THE HOLLYWOOD REPORTER


After, we'll go to Pho Lemongrass for dinner and discussion.

See you at the movie,

John

results.description:
Hi everyone! 

In addition to the regular bi-weekly Bible studies on the 1st and 3rd Saturdays, we're going to offer these Singles/family-oriented bi-weekly Bible studies on the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month.   Topics for the 2nd/4th Saturdays will be relevant to being a single Christian in today's world, with topics determined by you!  

The topic for April 9 is "Serving God as a Single Christian".  What special opportunities do we have to serve God when we are single?  What lessons does God want us to learn during this phase in our lives?  We look forward to hearing your thoughts and questions and turning to the Bible for guidance!

You're always welcome to come to any Bible Studies that fit your schedule. The studies will be structured as independent sessions, so you won't be lost if you miss one!

I hope you can join us!
results.name: 2nd & 4th Saturday Bible Study: "Serving God as a Single Christian"

results.description:
Let's begin "The Bond Book" by Annette Thau.


Annette Thau is a former municipal bond analyst for Chase Manhattan Bank and a visiting scholar at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. You may have seen her articles in AAII Journal. The Bond Book is written specifically for the individual investor, with clear writing, prudent insight, and easy mathematics.

On Saturday April 9 let's cruise through chapters 1-5.

All are welcome, even if you have no investing experience or have not read the book. We usually use highlights of the book as a general framework for discussion but topics often vary. Our goal is to learn together. All levels of investing experience are welcome. We look forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
Hi everyone! 

In addition to the regular bi-weekly Bible studies on the 1st and 3rd Saturdays, we're going to offer these Singles/family-oriented bi-weekly Bible studies on the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month.   Topics for the 2nd/4th Saturdays will be relevant to being a single Christian in today's world, with topics determined by you!  

Although the topics focus on the challenges and opportunities of being a single Christian in the modern world, you don't have to be single to come!  It would be great to have some married people participate and provide their perspective as well.

The topic for April 9 is "Serving God as a Single Christian".  What special opportunities do we have to serve God when we are single?  What lessons does God want us to learn during this phase in our lives?  We look forward to hearing your thoughts and questions and turning to the Bible for guidance!

You're always welcome to come to any Bible Studies that fit your schedule. The studies will be structured as independent sessions, so you won't be lost if you miss one!  Members of the Live Out Loud and Singles in Christ meetups will be joining us for a more dynamic meeting!

I hope you can join us!

results.description:
Join fellow members of the SSDOMG as we enjoy a Saturday Evening Potluck Social! We've run a potluck or two in the past and found that people enjoyed them, so Mike and Angela decided to do it again as we lead up to our 10th Anniversary Celebration this Summer. So, pull out your favorite recipe or grab something from the supermarket. Enjoy an evening with the SSDOMG without having to figure out the tax and tip!

Special note on accessibility:

This event is being held in an upper-level unit in a building that does NOT have an elevator! If climbing stairs is a problem, this may not be the event for you.

We will be gathering at my (Angela's) home so here are some ground rules and guidelines.

*SSDOMG Members Only

*You have to have attended at least 2 events with the SSDOMG

*Angela will provide paper goods, plasticware, water, tea, and hot chocolate.

In order to coordinate things, we're putting a list of food and beverage items below. When you RSVP, please choose at least one item to bring and note what you're bringing in a comment on the event page.

-Appetizers: Limit of 2, max of one hot item. <Angela>

-Beverages: 2 for up to 10 attendees, 3 if more than 10 people (including the organizers) are scheduled to attend. If you're bringing a beverage, please bring 2 of whatever you choose (and try not to bring exactly what someone else is bringing!) Soft drinks like regular soda, juice, coffee, etc are fine. Adult beverages are allowed with the expectation that people will, as the industry likes to say, enjoy them responsibly.  I have tea, hot chocolate and water in my home available for you all.

-Desserts: Up to 2.  <Ellen>

-Main Dishes/Side Dishes: Looking for at least 3 w/ a maximum of 5. <Mike>, <Jeanne>


-Salads: Maximum of 2. <Barbara>

My kitchen space is limited, so hot items are best brought hot. Please contact me if you will need to heat an item.

Allergies: If you have an allergy (food or otherwise) please note it on the event wall. Even though my home is a smoke-free zone, neighbors are allowed to smoke in their own units. I can attest that I do smell cigarette smoke on occasion. In addition, even though my home is animal-free, neighbors are allowed to have small pets. We do have a cat in the building.

Plan to join us on Saturday, April 9th @ 5:30pm to approximately 9pm (or later!) for a fun evening of socializing and eating in a relaxing environment!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Saturday Evening Potluck Social

Saturday, April 9th @ 5:30pm

Angela’s Condo Braintree, MA 02184

Organizers/Hosts: Angela and Mike



Minimum and Maximum: We desire a minimum of 6 attendees by 10am on Wednesday, April 6th (extended from 6pm on Monday, April 4th). The maximum number of attendees is approximately 15 people.

RSVP Deadline: Friday, April 8th @ 6pm / No new RSVPs will be accepted after 10am on Saturday, April 9th.

Guests: None as this is a Members-Only event.

Late Arrivals: So that we may all enjoy the food and each other’s company without having to “wait a few more minutes as another dish is on the way” or be left wondering where you are, we ask that you please arrive by 6pm. Please call if you will be any later.  If you are unable to arrive until 6:30pm, please choose a dessert or beverage to bring, rather than an appetizer, main course or side dish.

Event Fee: NONE! The only cost is the cost of the items you bring. You get to choose your own price range. ;)

Inclement Weather: TBD - Please see our Weather policy on the About page (scroll to the bottom and click on "Weather").

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Directions, including phone #s (to be used only if necessary) will be emailed to all Yes RSVPs around the time of the RSVP deadline. Located near Exit 17 on Route 3, the Braintree T, and along a bus stop. Please be sure to read the Directions email as it will include parking information.
results.name: Saturday Evening Potluck Social!

results.description:
We heard that you like salted meats to go with your beverages. 


Fogo de Chao is a Brazilian steakhouse.  That means it's the Bloodsport of steakhouses, where they just keep bringing you more meat until you say "Matte."  They will feed you steak, chicken, and pork until you explode like a certain character from Monty Python's Meaning of Life.  

They've also got a nice selection of wines.  Because we're civilized.

I feel bad at having to cancel the Salty Pig dinner, but I'd rather cancel and look like a jerk, than have people show up and be told there's a 4 hour wait to be seated.   So it's Fogo to the rescue for those who still want to do something on Saturday.

The endless parade of meats costs $50.  There's also a rather sizable and delicious buffet of things that are *not* steak, for those so inclined, that's included with the cost of dinner.

Fogo is right in Copley sq.  There are parking garages nearby, plus valet for $20.  There's also the Copley T stop a mere block away.

The Salty Pig dinner is still on the radar, it'll just have to happen at a later date.

Come, and prepare for the meat-sweats!

http://fogodechao.com/location/boston

Cibo Matto translates to “crazy food,” and you might indeed find yourself stunned by some of the flavor combinations at this Mansfield restaurant, which opened in November in a space formerly occupied by a Bertucci’s... Chef/owner Peter Kuplast says that preparations and ingredients “depend on the season”—winter brings a lot of braising, while summer brings a bounty of sprightly vegetables. And a member of the kitchen staff brings Filipino flavors, so the traditional Italian menu is buoyed by Asian accents.

Drinks, Appetizes, Pizza, Salads, Entrees and of course desserts - whatever you choose will be scrumptious!  We will enjoy great food, fun conversations and lots of smiles and laughs! We always do!

Event is for 16 members and a wait list will be automatic if anyone has to cancel.  Looking forward to trying this new restaurant right in Mansfield!

results.description:
Join us for drinks at Amrhein's in Southie to kick off our first YWWNO night out!  We decided not to schedule a dinner for our first event to keep it casual and give people the opportunity to drop by and meet other new members without feeling obligated to stay through an entire dinner. We hope to see you there!

FYI - If you are not familiar with Southie, Amrhein's is just off the Southeast Expressway (exit 18), one block from the Broadway T station on West Broadway. They have a parking lot adjacent to the building so parking shouldn't be an issue if you are driving in.

results.description:
We will once again have a ballroom basics lesson before our regular monthly dance at South Shore Dancers. "Ballroom Basics" is a 1/2 hour introduction to one or two of the dances that are danced at the area ballroom dances. You won't become an expert by coming for these, but it will give you a taste for the experience, and hopefully whet your appetite for one of the most enjoyable and healthy social activities you can get involved in: dancing!
This lesson is free for anyone who would like to try out dancing. You'll be charged the standard $12.00 entry fee, but if all you want is the basic lesson, that will be refunded at the end of the lesson if you decide to go elsewhere for the night. But of course we hope you'll stay for the night.
In April we have one of our favorite themes "Denim & Lace". We'll still be doing ballroom dance, but DJ Lestyn will no doubt throw a couple of country tunes our way. For the basic lesson, we'll teach a few figures of East Coast Swing and hope you can join us.
Because our dances have been pretty well-attended lately, you should make a reservation by calling Tom @[masked] if you plan to join us. Come early so we can start right on time!
results.name: Ballroom Basic Lesson

results.description:
Winchester Drum Circle is held on the 2nd Saturday of each month at Yoga Mandala, 750 Main St. 2nd floor, Winchester, MA from 7:00 to 9:00 pm. The parking and the entrance is on the right side of the building. Shoes will have to be removed before entering the studio. $5/per person.

This circle is lightly facilitated by Cathy Stacy and/or Donald Goldman. We usually play traditional African rhythms, but not always. We encourage beginners, intermediate and advanced drummers, didgers, other percussionists and dancers to share this beautiful space with us creating beautiful rhythms.

If you do not yet have a drum we will most likely have a djembe for you.

Please join us for this open and welcoming circle.
results.name: Winchester Drum Circle

Enjoy a Game of Pool. Shoot some Darts. Meet up with Friends.

At F1 Boston, the fun doesn’t stop on the track. Our billiards parlor features seven championship Brunswick pool tables. Comfortable leather seating, a relaxing lounge atmosphere, dart boards and bar service make it a wonderful place to enjoy some fun and conversation.

The billiards parlor is open to the public during F1 Boston's regular hours. The billiards parlor is also available for use for private parties. Contact our event staff for more information.

Reminder: Absolutely no drinking is allowed before you race at F1 Boston.

Before or after your game, stop into Ascari Cafe @F1 Boston for a meal or light bite.

results.description:
The next Cape Ann Contra Dance will be Saturday, April 9, at the Magnolia Library Community Center, 1 Lexington Avenue, Gloucester, MA.

The dancing starts at 7:00 PM. No experience is necessary. All dances are taught. Dancers of all ages are welcome; attendees range from eight years to 80 plus years! Everyone has a great time listening and dancing to the live music provided by the Cape Ann Contra Band and Friends.

There is a requested donation of $10 per dancer, dancers younger than 16 are free.

This event is supported in part by a grant from the Gloucester Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency. The Cape Ann Contra Dances are organized and produced by Folk Life Studio.

Drinking water is available. Please bring water bottles to reduce the use of paper cups. Other non-alcoholic drinks and finger food snacks are welcomed to share during the break.

For more information,
contact [masked]


or https://www.facebook.com/events/1543303335969347/

results.description:
Israel a country that’s rich in wine history, yet its wines remain largely misunderstood and under-appreciated by the U.S. market. Certainly, the industry has evolved over the past 30 years, as winemakers have learned the complexities of their terroir, climate tendencies, resiliency of their vines and the best way to tie all of these elements together. The resulting wines are the best the country has ever offered.  20 years ago, more wineries and well-trained winemakers brought New World knowledge and techniques to the Israeli wine industry and the industry changed to focus on quality, and not quantity.

I love to cook and plan to make some small plates from  celebrity Israeli chef  Michael Solomonov and his cookbook Zahav.  The cookbook showcases the melting-pot cooking of Israel - perfect with the Israeli wine theme! 


You may have to search a bit to find an Israeli wine that is not Yarden, which is the most common.  So if you find Yarden and something else, please select the something else so that we have a more diverse tasting.


Address provided to confirmed attendee list close to the event date. I live outside of Medford Square. With planning because these buses do not run frequently in the evenings and weekends, I live a 5-minute walk from the 94,  95, 96, 101, and 134 buses.

Please bring $10 to contribute toward food, a bottle of Israeli wine in a paper wine bag, and 4 glasses.
results.name: A Taste of Israel

venue.name: Spain: Barcelona, San Sebastian, La Rioja Region, Madrid, Seville

results.description:
11-14 days Food & Wine Tours
$3400- $4800
(Price varies upon single occupancy, optional 3 day extension in Seville, and 2 optional excursions)

**APRIL 9, 2016 is leave date. (Meetup won't let me schedule it out if it's over a year in advance)
Trips should be booked 9 months in advance or sooner to guarantee spots on tour dates.

Bring along significant others, family & friends!

From the Cava of Catalonia to the pintxos of Basque country, Spain’s cuisine is calling you. Taste your way through this colorful country, discovering its rich history and traditions as you go. Sample regional dishes and take in the culture of Barcelona and Madrid, savor San Sebastian’s world-famous fare and taste tempranillo wines of La Rioja and Ribera del Duero. Let the flavors of these vibrant regions of Spain surprise and entice you.

Your tour includes:

• Airfare

• 9 nights in handpicked hotels

• Breakfast daily, 3 lunches, 4 three-course dinners with beer or wine, 4 wine tastings

• Private deluxe motor coach

• Multilingual Tour Director

• Guided sightseeing & select entrance fees

Your tour highlights:

• The colors & flavors of La Boquería market

• Tasty tapas in Barcelona & Madrid

• Cava: Spain’s white sparkling wine

• Pintxos in San Sebastian, a new culinary capital

• Tempting tempranillo wines of Rioja & Ribera del Duero

• Scenic views of Spain’s vineyards & villages
results.name: April 2016 - Food & Wine Trip: A Taste of Spain

Be aware our last three shows SOLD OUT.
Purchase advance tickets with NO FEE here.
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/laughing-liberally-boston-tickets-16436562200?ref=ebtnebtckt

With the 2016 Presidential primaries kicking into high gear, with Donald Trump and Ted Cruz saying crazy things on a nearly daily basis, we need progressive laughs now more than ever. That’s why we have Laughing Liberally Boston, a monthly progressive political comedy show featuring some Boston’s top liberal and progressive comedians.

Laughing Liberally Boston is hosted by comedian, satirist and progressive talk radio host Matthew Filipowicz. For more information about Matthew, visit http://matthewf.net/

Comedians on the April 9th bill include: Christine An, Kwasi Mensah, Pamela Ross, and Jere Pilapil.

In addition to some of the finest progressive comedians Boston has to offer, each Laughing Liberally Boston show will feature a special interview segment with a local political figure, journalist or activist. This month’s guest is Nadeem Mazen. Nadeem is an educator, community organizer and member of the Cambridge City Council.

Laughing Liberally Boston takes place the second Saturday of every month, with the next show on Saturday April 9th at 8pm at the Riot Theater, 146a South Street, Jamaica Plain, MA. Admission is $8.

Singer, saxophonist, flutist, actor Stan Strickland has performed throughout the United States, Europe, Scandinavia, the Caribbean, New Zealand and the former Soviet Union. In addition to numerous radio and television appearances, Stan has performed in many clubs and concert halls, including Jordan and Symphony Halls in Boston, Carnegie Recital Hall and Town Hall in New York, and at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. Stan has performed with jazz greats Yusef Lateef, Pharoah Sanders, Herbie Mann, Danilo Perez, Shirley Scott and Marlena Shaw.

results.description:
Let's dance salsa!

Saturday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Saturday featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00 pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2 am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet at 9 pm (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will try  to post a Meetup sign at one of these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.  Last time I asked for permission and  management informed me that posting signs was not allowed. However, if you are on time, you will definitely connect with the group.  

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 


Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds. 

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.  


A tip, if you are a beginner, you definitely want to come early and participate in the lesson and connect with other beginners.  The first half of this event is the most beginner friendly part of the night.  Advanced dancers usually come later  in the night after the lessons are done.  Some beginners may feel intimated arriving so late in the night.  

I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com
results.how_to_find_us: Right side of the stage at 9 pm sharp!
results.name: Lets Dance Salsa!  at the Havana Club in Central Square! Lesson Included!

results.description:
Hey!

results.description:
We're giving away 3-day passes to An Event Apart Boston, a nationally-renowned web design and development conference! Two lucky winners will each be registered for a 3-day Conference + A Day Apart pass worth $1,390 each, which features industry-leading speakers, a hands-on workshop session, networking and, of course, food and drinks. View the event schedule for details.


Not interested in entering the contest? An Event Apart is offering $100 off any 2- or 3-day pass with discount code AEAGDI.


What is An Event Apart Boston?

An Event Apart Boston is an intensely educational learning session for passionate practitioners of standards-based web design. If you care about code as well as content, usability as well as design, An Event Apart is the conference you’ve been waiting for.


When is An Event Apart Boston?

• Monday, May 16, 2016

• Tuesday, May 17, 2016

• Wednesday, May 18, 2016

View the event schedule for details. Note that you must be able to attend all three days in order to enter this contest.


Where is An Event Apart?

This year's An Event Apart Boston is happening at Boston Marriott Copley Place. View Google map.


How can I find out more about An Event Apart Boston?

View the An Event Apart Boston website for details, including a speaker line-up.


How do I enter?

First, a few ground rules: 

•To enter, you must be able to attend all three days of the conference (May 16-18). When RSVPing, you will be asked if you can attend all three days. If the answer is no, or you're not sure, please don't RSVP until you know you can attend all three days.


• Be sure to enter your email when you RSVP! If you win, GDI Boston will contact you via email on April 10, 2016. You'll have until April 17 at 11:45pm EST to claim your ticket before a 'second chance' drawing occurs. RSVPs without an email address will not be entered in the drawing.


• Each pass is non-transferrable. If you win, you must personally be able to attend all three days.


Sound good? RSVP now to enter!

What if I can only attend two days?

While you won't be able to enter the contest, feel free to use the discount code AEAGDI when registering on the An Event Apart Boston website for $100 off any 2- or 3-day pass.

Interested in discovering events like this, classes, workshops, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!
results.name: Contest: Win a three-day pass to An Event Apart!

We'll meet at Faneuil Hall for brunch (exact time and location of brunch to be determined).

results.description:
We'll hike approx 6 to 8+ miles on carriage roads and trails including close to three miles on the Bay Circuit Trail

Borderland State Park


259 Massapoag Avenue

North Easton, MA 02356

[masked]

[masked]

Daily Parking Fee: $5 resident, $6 non-resident

Borderland is one of the most historically significant tracts of publicly owned land in the Commonwealth. Created in the early 1900s by artist and suffragist Blanche Ames and her botanist husband Oakes, Borderland offers many of the same pleasures that the Ames family enjoyed: walking and horseback riding on woodland trails, fishing and canoeing in the ponds, or, in winter, ice-skating and sledding.

In 1906, Oakes Ames and his wife Blanche purchased land on the border of Sharon and Easton. The country estate they named “Borderland” remained in the family for 65 years. In 1971, two years after the death of Blanche Ames, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts acquired the estate and opened it as a state park. The family’s home, a three-storey stone mansion built in 1910, still stands. Its twenty rooms are furnished much as they were when the Ameses lived here; many of Blanche Ames’ paintings grace the walls. Their illustrious histories remain in the house which is open for scheduled tours

The Fine Print: 

No dogs or guests are allowed on BSOT hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events.

Duration: Approximately 3-4+ hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

 You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace of 2+ mph. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults.run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ <a>http://www.hikesafe.c</a>;... the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

Preregistration is open for April's Spring Handicap Go Tournament! To get yourself entered into the competitors' lists, just message James with your name, your playing rank, and your AGA number if you know it. Preregistering helps get the paperwork portion of the tournament done earlier, so we can jump straight into matches right away on the day of the games!

Newcomers are welcome, if you have any questions about the sign up process or tournament structure, just message me and I'll talk you through it.

We're also looking for one or two people interested in becoming assistant Tournament Directors. For the small price of helping out with setup and teardown and doing some administrative work, you'll have your entry fee waived! Again, message James to enquire the details.

With the US Go Congress coming up in Boston in August, you'll want to take advantage of every last chance to practice in tournament games that you can get! Good luck and good game to all!

Here are the hard details:
When:
Sunday, April 10th! On-site registration will open at 9:45 and the first round of play is projected to begin at 10:30.

Where:
Boylston Chess Club
40 Norris St, Cambridge MA
The Boylston Chess Club rents rooms in the basement of a condo at this address. To find the entrance, follow the building's driveway along the right side of the building and go down the set of stairs you'll find. Street parking in Cambridge is free on Sundays.

Format:
Tournament consists of four AGA rated games played with handicap under the Japanese rules. Main time is 45 minutes with a Canadian overtime period of 25 moves/5minutes. Komi is 7.5 in even games, .5 in handicapped games.

As this is an AGA rated event, all players will need to have a membership with the AGA which you can sign up for at usgo.org or fill out a form for it on the day of the games.

Registration fee is $20 for MGA members and $25 for non-members with a $5 discount offered to players who pregister.

First Place Prize: $50
Second Place Prize: $30
Third Place Prize: $20

results.description:
A day full of Lightroom This is a day to get you started with Lightroom. It's split into two parts: 

Morning Session: Start off right 

An essential of Lightroom is that you organize your image files in a consistent manner. Unfortunately many users fail to grasp this important essential and end up in a mess. If you are new to Lightroom you should definitely take the time to learn the necessary organizational steps to creating a consistent approach to importing and structuring your files.

 We will cover: 

• What Lightroom is and what it isn't 

• What is a Lightroom file 

• The Lightroom Catalog

•  Collections and Smart Collections 

• The import dialog 

• Structuring your files

•  Naming conventions that work 

• Tagging and keywording your files 

• Picking and rejecting files

•  Facial recognition

•  Searching and finding 

Afternoon Session: So what can you do with it?

 Lightroom has become a very quick and useful tool for post-processing your files but many users never get beyond using the simple sliders. However, Lightroom has some partially hidden and lesser known features that can make your post processing even better. In this session you will learn how to use the tolls in the develop module to edit and post-process your images like a pro.

 We will cover:

•  Establishing a workflow 

• Where to start 

• The Lightroom Process engine 

• THe Histogram and why it is your best friend 

• White Balance and the eye dropper 

• THe BASIC tool set 

• The secret life of Curves

•  Addressing color shifts with curves

•  Color improvements with HSL 

• Cloning and Healing 

• The gradient tools and how to get the best from them 

• Sharpening and noise reduction 

• Straightening and distorting your images 

• Cropping and rotating 

• Removing Haze 

• Professional looking Black and White conversions

•  Creating and using presets and brush presets 

• The targeted adjustment brush and why it's so useful 

• 


We will begin at 10am and break for lunch around 12.30pm for one hour. (Not provided) Returning at 1.30pm for an intensive afternoon session. 

The cost is $150 for the whole day. 

It is recommended that you complete both parts of the day to gain a good understanding of the workings of Lightroom. 

You are welcome to bring along your laptop on which to follow along, but there will be no time devoted to getting your software to work, or to fixing issues you may have with your laptop. The version of Lightroom used for the class is Vightroom CC 2015.

How does it get even better that and what else is possible? This 8 hour workshop is a certification which also allows you to offer the Bars in your healing practice.

results.description:
Humanist of theYear Award

Juliet Schor, Professor of Sociology, Boston College

Prof. Schor, a renowned scholar and author, has written extensively on a range of economic and cultural issues.  A leading voice on the dynamics of American consumerism, she has proposed new models of growth and sustainability.

Living an ethical life is no longer a matter of individual action.  Climate change has linked how we live in the US to impacts throughout the globe.  Prof. Schor will discuss what the global ethics of climate change means for Americans, with particular attention to patterns of spending, working and activism. She will draw on her research on the links between greenhouse gas emissions and economic outcomes such as hours of work, economic growth, and the extent of inequality and suggest ways forward that improve well-being and achieve radical emissions cuts.
results.name: New Perspectives on Climate and Economy

results.description:
This event opens to rsvp'ing 10 days in advance.

The trail is 8.5 miles from Arlington center to Bedford and we ride at a moderate pace.This event auto-repeats monthly and may be leaderless.

Lunch afterwards at Not Your Average Joes, 645 Mass Ave.

Suggested donation $1 for Meetup fees.

This ride happens only if its a nice, clear day above 40 .

Wear a helmet, bring water and sunscreen, watch out for children on the trail, and have a good time!

The Minuteman Bikeway passes through the historic area where the American Revolution began in April 1775.

Today, the Minuteman Bikeway is one of the most popular and successful rail-trails in the United States, enjoyed for both healthy recreation and transportation.

The bikeway has become a new type of “Main Street” where neighbors and strangers alike come together while riding, walking, or skating on the path.

In 2008, Rails-to-Trails Conservancy inducted the Minuteman Bikeway into the national Rail-Trail Hall of Fame.

Why not come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 11:00 AM Sunday?  We will do this at the turf field of Belmont High School, as we done a few times in recent months.  We have no official claim to the field, so hopefully nobody will kick us off.  A few things to remember:

·  This is the "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.  That said, we highly encourage all players to wear shin guards to protect against accidental knobbling.

·  Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy. 

·  Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather

·  Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

$20 for adults. $15 for students under 18. If you're under 13, you must be accompanied by an adult.


Space is very limited so if you are interested in attending, please visit www.nesfa.org/negc/ and pre-register as soon as possible.

There will also be opportunities to run 'on the spot' competitions, where members play games for prizes. These games will not be scheduled, but will be announced at the convention itself.

results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers,

Let's head to the Harvard Museum of Natural History to sketch! 

Plan is to meet in lobby of museum at 11:00am, then meet back in lobby to share our work at 1:00pm.

Don't forget your Massachusetts ID so you can get in for FREE!

The Harvard Museum of Natural History was created in 1998 as the “public face” of three research museums — the Museum of Comparative Zoology, the Harvard Mineralogical and Geological Museum, and the Harvard University Herbaria (I did not know this was a word).

 It hosts a variety of natural world exhibitions, including a large glass flower collection. The museum is on the Harvard University campus and is the school's most visited attraction. 

The details for this event: The museum entrance is free before 12:00PM for all Massachusetts residents with proof of residency so bring your state ID (or rental agreement?). Otherwise the museum is $10 for students and $12 for adults. If you have a Harvard ID, are a Harvard Museums member, a teacher, an ASTC passport program member, or apart of active duty military, the entrance is also free. 

Drawing is encouraged in the galleries, but the use of clay, paints, pastels, and chalk is NOT permitted. So bring your pens, pencils and colored pencils! I think that about covers it, hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the lobby of the museum at 11:00am and be sure to get your free admission ticket first!
results.name: Let's Sketch! The Harvard Museum of Natural History

results.description:
Think of this as a creative mini-retreat. It's designed primarily for writers—of all experience levels, working in any genre. Although we've booked the space for 6 hours, you're welcome to arrive and leave whenever you like. 

WHAT WE'LL DO: 

• Noon: Doors open.

• 12:30 p.m.: Write to easy creative prompts (if there's interest). 

• 1 p.m. sharp: Begin writing.

Although we'll be in the same large room, we'll be writing in companionable silence, talking only during breaks. If you'd like to have a conversation with someone, you're welcome to step into another room upstairs or head to a nearby coffee shop.


• About 4:30 p.m.: People will be invited to briefly share from their work, if they wish. (Sharing is optional and time will be limited.) No one will critique anyone's work unless the writer requests feedback. 

• 5:30-6 p.m.: Clean up and depart. 

AMENITIES: The Braintree Community Arts Center is a newly converted two-story house about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the road (Route 37). We'll have the house all to ourselves for the day. It's bright, pleasant, and equipped with tables, chairs, restrooms, a coffeemaker, a fridge, a countertop range, free parking, and Wi-Fi. I will provide a few books for inspiration, and an extension cord and power strip for power.

WHAT TO BRING: Yourself, your writing projects and writing implements (computer or  writing notebook and pen, or journal). Bring your own beverage. Feel free to bring a snack to share—but that’s entirely optional.

COST: $15 (cash or check), regardless of how long you stay. This goes toward space-use costs and our Meetup fee.  

HOW TO RESERVE A SPOT: RSVP "yes" using Meetup's RSVP function. The RSVP list is our official headcount for the day, so it's the only way to sign up—emailing the organizer or posting messages on the site won't hold a spot.

CANCELLATIONS: If we need to cancel due to weather or any other reason, we'll post a message on the Web site and e-mail all "yes" RSVPs as far in advance as possible. 

REMINDER ABOUT ABOUT RSVPs: Your RSVP is a reservation, and we're trusting that you'll honor it. If you can't make it, please change your RSVP from "yes" to "no" at least 24 hours in advance. If you cancel with less than 24 hours notice, or if you RSVP "yes" and then don't show up, you'll be asked to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

Looking forward to seeing you!

                                         $$$ About Money $$$

Managing restaurant events is so much easier when everyone brings cash, so planning ahead is always a great idea:

(1) PLEASE BRING CASH to pay for your meal.

Event:
Our monthly Boston Area Furry Luncheon

When:
Every second Sunday of each month, at 1:00PM.

The next luncheon will be held on
Sunday, April 10, 2016
For those of you who need a month’s notice, the following luncheon will be held on:
Sunday, May 8, 2016


Where:
The 99 in Chalestown
29-31 Austin Street; Charlestown, MA[masked]
Phone: (617)[masked] . It’s a short walk from the Community College T stop, on the Orange Line, and there is plenty of free parking. The prices for meals are reasonable. Finally, there’s free popcorn for those of you who can’t afford a full meal and vegetarian options for us herbivores. Just ask the wait staff. ^!^

For more details, you can go to: http://www.99restaurants.com/ .

(Sorry to say it, but we’ve got to have) Rules:
We don’t need to make a reservation, thus there is no need to RSVP (and hardly anyone ever does). Just simply show up.

No one under the age of 16 will be admitted. No one of ages 16 or 17 will be admitted without permission from their parents. The PDF’s for the permission slips are posted here: https://www.furaffinity.net/view/5929875/ please follow the instructions provided. I know this may sound silly, but I’m just trying to prevent the possibility of any sort of trouble.

Note: It is not essential, but I’m encouraging each and every one of us to tip. This will ensure that we maintain a good relationship with the staff. The minimum wage for “tipped services” is about half that of other forms of employment. Therefore, most waitstaff rely heavily on tips, as their source of income. An average tip would be between 15% and 20% of the total cost of your meal. If you need any help calculating this amount, please let us know. Also, I can teach short-cuts for doing this in one’s head. ^!^

Questions, Comments, and Contact Info:
If you have any questions or comments, feel free to send me a Note.

Also, if you would like to lend a paw, claw, hoof, wing, fin, tentacle, mandible, or whatever, in coordinating this event, I’ll be glad to hear from you. ^!^
