results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

(NOTE: In the very rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.

results.description:
Welcome new members!  Please note, RSVPs are required to attend this 35-person, multi-site game night.  The open RSVP spots on Meetup are for new members.


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have about 35 attendees each week, including regulars and new members.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.  If you are having a hard time getting a spot, please send a message to the organizer and we will try to work something out!

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you have a good time, we ask new members for a one-time donation of $5 towards our site fees.  Other than that, game night is completely free!

4. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  (We do play some light games, but if that's the main thing you want to play, please try our Light Game Night instead!)  Our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right.  We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5.00 that goes towards site fees.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

Come draw some dynamic poses with us at Damon's studio- we do shorter poses here, 5 minutes to start, and ranging through 10, 20, and 30 minute poses. Informal setting in Damon's painting studio, surrounded by his paintings and work in progress.

You can pay online in advance when you RSVP, and save time for drawing during the session. Please customize the amount you're paying online according to whether you've paid your membership this month or not ($10 for members, $25 for a one-time drop in- which can be converted to a membership should you come back that same month). You may also pay your $25 monthly membership when that comes due each month online either together with the payment for the drawing session or separately through the link to the left on the sidebar.

Parking is on-street legally for two hours for people without Somerville parking permits, BUT WE PREFER THAT YOU PARK IN THE LOT AROUND BACK, WHICH IS OPEN till about 11PM. The building is a working factory, so the lot is monitored and safe, though it is a bit of a walk around the building to the front door. Please do not leave your car in the lot past 11pm or so, or on Saturdays past three pm, as they lock the gate if there is not late shift and your car will be locked in until the next shift starts at the factory.

About the book: In Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?, Mindy invites readers on a tour of her life and her unscientific observations on romance, friendship, and Hollywood, with several conveniently placed stopping points for you to run errands and make phone calls. Mindy Kaling really is just a Girl Next Door—not so much literally anywhere in the continental United States, but definitely if you live in India or Sri Lanka.

If you'd like to participate, stop by the circulation desk at the Main branch (40 Washington St.) and ask for a copy of the book; they are held at the desk under the Grownups 20/30s book club account. results.description:
Ike Walker, Database Architect at Flite, talks about the common_schema project: a self contained schema which includes a set of sophisticated views, routines and a specialized scripting language (QueryScript), simplifying MySQL server administration and analysis.

common_schema is aimed to be imported onto any MySQL server, on any platform. Along with INFORMATION_SCHEMA and PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA, common_schema becomes a valuable tool for one's server. In this session we will see how common_schema adds new capabilities to the MySQL server or otherwise makes complex tasks easy. We will review:

* How to install (import) common_schema
* Schema analysis views
* Process & security views and routines
* Status monitoring and transaction analysis
* SQL generating views and eval()
* QueryScript: an SQL based scripting language

We will see how common_schema/QueryScript assist in common tasks such as alleviating load from heavyweight queries, killing queries/connections, analyzing deadlocks, managing tables on multiple databases, iterating, scripting and more.


------------- Logistics -------------

MIT's map with the building (E51) highlighted: http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?selection=E5...

MIT's map with the Kendall square T stop highlighted: http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?selection=L5... (the stop is in red on that map, and you can see E51 in the bottom right)

MIT's maps with parking lot information: http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?selection=P4... and http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?selection=P5...

Note that MIT lots are free to park in after 3 pm or so, even if it says "reserved for faculty"

Free pizza and soda will be served, so please RSVP accurately.

To RSVP anonymously, please login to the Meetup site with the e-mail address "admin at sheeri dot com" and the password "guest". For more information, see: http://www.meetup.com/mysqlbos/calendar/
results.name: common_schema: DBA'S Framework for MySQL

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

This Harvard Kennedy School, Belfer Center, Future of Diplomacy Project Seminar is open to the public. Event link HERE.

:: :: ::

Description: With the entire world waiting for the American people to pick their next Commander and Chief, the stakes are high. The candidates for President of the United States have presented what seems like contrasting visions for U.S. foreign policy. But is U.S. foreign policy really so malleable that one single person can dramatically change course, even if President?

Join Ambassador (Ret.) Derek Shearer and Professor Stephen Walt to discuss the 2016 U.S. Presidential elections and what is at stake from a foreign policy perspective.

Ambassador Derek Shearer is the Stuart Chevalier Professor of Diplomacy and World Affairs and heads the McKinnon Center for Global Affairs at Occidental College. Ambassador Shearer served in the Clinton Administration in the Commerce Department and then as Ambassador to Finland. He is the author of several books and publications, and his articles have appeared in the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and the International Herald Tribune.

Stephen M. Walt is the Robert and Renée Belfer Professor of International Affairs and is Faculty Chair of the International Security Program at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government. He previously taught at Princeton University and the University of Chicago, where he served as Master of the Social Science Collegiate Division and Deputy Dean of Social Sciences. He serves on the editorial boards of Foreign Policy, Security Studies, International Relations, and Journal of Cold War Studies, and as Co-Editor of the Cornell Studies in Security Affairs, published by Cornell University Press.

:: :: ::

Contact: Future of Diplomacy Project Executive Director Cathryn Cluver - One Brattle Square, Mailbox 134 Cambridge - Harvard Kennedy School, Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs - Email: [masked] - Phone:[masked]

:: :: ::

Will history repeat? ... Chicago ... 1968 ... ... ...

Question:

This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks? 

Answer:

• For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!" 

Thanks to the efficiency and BI (business intelligence) of Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org), founded about 35 years ago by self-reported vegetarian Nancy Jamison, we have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food. 

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag). 

That's why it's posted on a meetup like this (not merely on a volunteer meetup). 

* There are tens of thousands of college students who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* There are tens of thousands (myriads) of homemakers and working individuals who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* Lots and lots of seniors AND needy folks, and there's no operational shame in prudent fiscal management if you know that you can get quality produce at a far lower price. 

[The snag is that, unlike in grocery stores - or even in Haymarket, your variety of produce is severely limited here because you're getting what Fair Foods sends to any specific site; you are unable to select from a broader arrangement of vegetables and a broader arrangement of fruits.  Typically, you get about 7-11 different items - about 5-8 different vegetables and 2-3 fruits, and you're often 'gifted' with extra items - 30 ounce jug of fresh hummus or lentil salad or chickpea salads, pound of garlic, large one-lb plastic container of ground pepper, or lots of other 'big items' we don't typically buy.] 

Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
The 2016 Charles Eliot Norton Professorship in Poetry has been awarded to Toni Morrison - The Origin of Others - The Literature of Belonging

A series of lectures by Toni Morrison.

These lectures are free, but tickets are required. Get Tix HERE. 

Tickets will be available starting at noon on the day of each lecture. Tickets will be available in person at Sanders Theatre or online HERE (handling fees apply). Limit of two tickets per person. Tickets valid until 3:45pm.

Lecture Six: The Foreigner's Home - Tuesday, April 12, 2016, 4pm

Sanders Theatre, 45 Quincy Street

:: :: ::

Lecture One: Romancing Slavery - Wednesday, March 2, 2016

Lecture Two: Being and Becoming the Stranger - Tuesday, March 8, 2016

Lecture Three: The Color Fetish - Wednesday, March 9, 2016

Lecture Four: Configurations of Blackness - Tuesday, March 22, 2016

Lecture Five: Narrating the Other - Monday, April 11, 2016

Lecture Six: The Foreigner's Home - Tuesday, April 12, 2016

:: :: ::

The Charles Eliot Norton Professorship in Poetry was endowed in 1925. Harvard's preeminent lecture series in the arts and humanities, the Norton Lectures recognize individuals of extraordinary talent who, in addition to their particular expertise, have the gift of wide dissemination and wise expression. The term "poetry" is interpreted in the broadest sense to encompass all poetic expression in language, music, or the fine arts. Past Norton Professors have included T.S. Eliot, Jorge Luis Borges, Leonard Bernstein, Czeslaw Milosz, John Cage, and Nadine Gordimer.
results.name: Toni Morrison

results.description:
We'll hike until closing time(dusk) taking our time to feed birds & take pictures! 

Ipswich River offers more than 12 miles of trails that invite you to explore the forests, meadows, and wetlands. A drumlin and esker, key landscape features, were formed by a glacier 15,000 years ago. Boulders stacked to create arches and a grotto setting, constructed in 1905, provide an adventurous walk along the Rockery Trail.

The sanctuary fee is $4.00 for non-Audubon members and free to members.

Duration: Approximately 2 hours,  Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared.Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), and snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme temperature cancels.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

For more info go to:
http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/ipswich-river/about

results.description:
Directed by Jon Favreau (“Iron Man”), based on Rudyard Kipling’s timeless stories and inspired by Disney’s classic animated film, “The Jungle Book” is an all-new live-action epic adventure about Mowgli (newcomer Neel Sethi), a man-cub who’s been raised by a family of wolves. But Mowgli finds he is no longer welcome in the jungle when fearsome tiger Shere Khan (voice of Idris Elba), who bears the scars of Man, promises to eliminate what he sees as a threat. Urged to abandon the only home he’s ever known, Mowgli embarks on a captivating journey of self-discovery, guided by panther-turned-stern mentor Bagheera (voice of Ben Kingsley), and the free-spirited bear Baloo (voice of Bill Murray). Along the way, Mowgli encounters jungle creatures who don’t exactly have his best interests at heart, including Kaa (voice of Scarlett Johansson), a python whose seductive voice and gaze hypnotizes the man-cub, and the smooth-talking King Louie (voice of Christopher Walken), who tries to coerce Mowgli into giving up the secret to the elusive and deadly red flower: fire.

The all-star cast also includes Lupita Nyong'o as the voice of the fiercely protective mother wolf Raksha, and Giancarlo Esposito as the voice of wolf pack’s alpha male Akela. “The Jungle Book” seamlessly blends live-action with photorealistic CGI animals and environments, using up-to-the-minute technology and storytelling techniques to immerse audiences in an enchanting and lush world. The wild adventure swings into theaters in 3D on April 15, 2016


https://youtu.be/WtR9tqPa48s

results.description:
Many people talk about personal branding, but what does that mean when you are a sales professional?  With the growing demands of sales people and sales managers, who has time to do all of that "social stuff"?

In this session, we will learn why it is important to start brand building and practical steps to creating your own "sales professional brand".  Lori Richardson of Score More Sales will share her insights into how to leverage social media, content marketing, and networking to expand your influence, build your credibility, and sell with more success.


Also a special shout out to Jackie at Appcues.  They are sponsoring the space for our April event at the awesome Landmark Center near Fenway.  So let Jackie and the Appcues team know we super appreciate the support!

*******


About Our Speaker

Lori Richardson is the founder and CEO of Score More Sales, a B2B sales "leads and leadership" company that provides a "Sales EKG" for sales teams to help determine areas of improvement. Lori is a thought leader on B2B front-line sales growth, leadership, and on women in B2B sales.  

Lori has been in and around B2B professional selling and sales leadership her entire adult life. She's writing a book and speaks around North America at associations and to company sales teams. Fun fact is that Lori was LinkedIn member #29,426 so she know how to use the tools and how to leverage social selling. 


*******

About Our Sponsors

• If you want great in-product experiences without writing code, visit Appcues


• If you are looking for a kickass mobile sales assistant app, download Spiro

• If you are seeking your next sales gig, set up your candidate profile on Hired

• If you want to extend your social selling reach, we recommend GrowthChamp


• If you need to increase the performance of your sales reps, talk to Selleration

• If you are running events and need better check-in software, Boomset is great

• If you need a live video platform for your events,  Livestream is your best bet

If you would like to learn more about being a sponsor, please reach out to Mark Birch at [masked] for more information.
results.name: Building Your Sales Brand w/ Lori Richardson

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by AKAMAI.


Java and Security: A Microservice Integration Platform

Application security becomes a more prominent concern when we move services into the cloud space. In this presentation, we introduce a micro service based platform that provides seamless web SSO integration using SAML or OAuth2, access control for applications and APIs behind a gateway. A SAML based identity provider supports not only enterprise SSO web integration, but also serves as the authentication provider for an OAuth2 server. This is a true SSO for both SAML based service providers and OAuth2 clients. The API gateway serves as an OAuth2 resource server to provide security for micro service behind it.  The platform uses Java and a few other languages and libraries, such as HTML5, Bootstrap, AngularJS, Spring Boot, Spring Cloud, RDBMS, LDAP and Liquibase.

Brandon Chen

Brandon Chen is a seasoned technologist with 16+ years experience in healthcare, telecommunication, and financial engineering sectors. Through out his professional life, he has been passionate about hands-on full-stack development. He led the design, development and deployment for a cloud based multi-tenancy identity and access management system for a major financial service company. After that, he started consulting practice in cloud and security related fields using his business acumen in product management and engineering process. Brandon is currently a partner consultant in NubeSecure LLC, an application and data security product and service provider.
results.name: Java and Security: A Microservice Integration Platform

results.description:
CALLING ALL HEART PLAYERS!

                        Tonight we'll play HEARTS

        Bring your decks of cards and let the games begin!

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a night of HEARTS.  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play a few tables of HEARTS.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
If you have never attended BITR (Berklee in the Round) before, you're in for a real treat! Berklee has numerous free music events, and this one is hands-down my favorite!

Berklee in the Round (BITR) occurs on the second Tuesday of every month. Each month a different faculty member selects four to five students and, if possible, one special guest (a visiting artist, touring songwriter, or other) and hosts a concert. The event, based on in-the-round performances at the famous Bluebird Cafe in Nashville, Tennessee, seats songwriters in a circle where they take turns playing their songs with the audience seated around the performers, lending a more intimate feel to the show. This months BITR will feature Jake Ohlbaum, Lauren Murphy, McKenna Flaherty, Tyler Perry, and Eva Cassel. For more information on who's playing, go here.

Admission: Free

PS - Please note that this event is cross-posted as:

http://www.meetup.com/Beginner-Singers-Songwriters-and-Musicians/events/230084308

http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Music-Jam/events/230084312/

http://www.meetup.com/Free-And-Cheap-Things-in-Boston/events/230084305/

http://www.meetup.com/SocialFun/events/230084314/

results.description:
We're back at ExtensionEngine this month. Thanks to our UX expert Jess for hosting this event! =)


The doors are security token access only after 6pm. When you arrive, call or text Nicole at[masked] and we'll let you in. The main door is surrounded by a few logos including ExtensionEngine (don't enter via the Citizen Bank entrance). Once you are inside, take the elevator down to the basement. Once you depart the elevator, walk straight and you'll see a glass conference room titled, "Yoda" and that's where we'll be! There will be posters to help clarify the location.

Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:45pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Jessica Pang is an Interactive Designer at ExtensionEngine, an online education software development company. She has spent the past 4 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.


Mel Choyce is a design engineer at Automattic, where she works mostly on design and front-end development. Feel free to ask her about UI design, UX and user testing, HTML/CSS, and any beginner WordPress questions.

Kelly Dwan is a WordPress developer and core contributor. Familiar with the ins and outs of WordPress, she's happy to answer any theme or plugin development questions, or anything PHP, JS, CSS, HTML.


Paige Eaton is a librarian turned Drupal developer. She loves sports, games, and long walks on the beach, but not too long. It's really tiring to walk on sand. Paige is helpful for questions about UX, HTML, CSS, some PHP, and is a good listener/sounding board for ideas & projects.

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)


Location

ExtensionEngine

196 Broadway


Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT
results.name: Project Night

Welcome fellow Partners, 

We hope you can join us for our first Meetup. 

Creating events comes naturally to me and many of you will recognize me as the entrepreneur of BostonVolunteer.org. I've very excited about Partners Boston, the business professionals community that a few of us have been building for many months. We've celebrated several popular meets outside of Meetup. 

Facts about Partners Boston:

1. Partners Boston is about building long-term business relationships. 

We expect all Partners to join us for 10 of the 12 yearly business referral give aways. 

2. You'll also meet your Partners outside of the group. Expect to meet one or two new partners each week. 

3. At the end of each meet we'll recognize to the group the business that we shared during the previous month. The people who share the most business will get great benefits such as their profile and link on our well respected website! 

4. We're limited to 25 small business owners and exceptional business professionals. Only one per professional so that there's no in-group competition for referrals. Join now (email me and introduce yourself) and block out your competition. 

5. We highly vet our members b/c we care that our referrals get the best results. If you're brand new please email me directly and introduce yourself! 


6. Lastly, we're actively seeking 2 more people for our Partners Leadership team. Interested? Please email me directly. 

We anticipate you joining us, 

Josh and Partners

This is the fourth in a series of one-hour, semi-private (4 person) clinics offered for four weeks by Terry Felty, PGA.  This session has been changed to a co-ed session.  Cost is $30 per person, per session (Terry's rate is $120 for one hour--see note below about cancelling)

You should sign up for the sessions independently because the lessons are not going to build on the previous week--however, we ask that to be fair to everyone, please sign up for a maximum of 2 sessions to start out until everyone's had a chance to sign up.

These clinic sessions are limited to four people each night and you must be a member of the ASGA to take advantage of these events.   See www.singlesgolf.com if you would like to join.

NOTE:  it is very important that you keep your RSVP up-to-date! Sometimes things happen that are out of your control, however, if you cancel within 48 hours of the event you must make sure there is a replacement for you to attend or you will be required to pay the $30 fee--it would not be fair to the other 3 who do attend to pick up your $30 share of the fee.

Please see Terry's website below for location, credentials, info about the facilities, etc.   This was a very successful series when we did it last year and I hear that participants took advantage of refreshments afterwards at Cafe Escadrille right around the corner!


Any questions, please contact me by clicking on my profile and select message to send a private email

http://www.bigsticksgolf.com/home/about-us/

Presentations:

Extreme Reach will be presenting on their use of AWS for a critical Talent rights service called 'TRUST';


For the brand advertising ecosystem, Extreme Reach is a cloud-based enterprise platform with core technology that's central to the seamless activation of TV + Video brand campaigns. Talent and Rights Usage Safety Tracking Tag, “TRUST” Tag, enables real-time verification that video ads running on digital media are compliant with talent and rights contract terms. The technology also provides time-sensitive details, previously unavailable, required to ensure on-time payment of performers that appear in the commercials.


Presenter: Mark Annati, VP, IT, Extreme Reach

On the topic of API, Chris Riley, Manager HKM Consulting LLC, will be presenting the following;

Abstract: Last year in November, the Linux Foundation announced the formation of the Open API initiative. This initiative is focused on extending the Swagger 2.0 specification to support meta-data for Restful APIs. This show of support has helped promote and increase the adoption of Swagger into a variety of solutions including AWS API Gateway, Smartbear API Testing solutions, WSO2 API Manager and others. 
This session will introduce users to the Swagger specification and how it can help AWS consumers rapidly generate meta-data that are interoperable in other tooling. Additionally the impact of Swagger on your DevOps / Microservices strategy will be demonstrated.

Contact Mark Annati, the moderator, at [masked] with interest in sponsoring (location/food) and presenting at future meetups.
Thank you.

results.description:
Join us for this special Café des Sciences with 

Dr Jeff Karp, Associate Professor at Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Principal Faculty at the Harvard Stem Cell Institute, and affiliate faculty at the Broad Institute and at the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology.

Dr Jeff Karp will give an inspiring talk about two of the most powerful tools used by his bio-research lab to solve problems in innovative ways, on a continuing basis: bioinspiration and radical simplicity. 

Jeff explains how his team has employed these tools and how they can succeed in any field. This talk opens exciting new paths to the continual innovation that is so important in today’s fast-changing world.

Schedule:

- 6:30PM: Welcome

- 6:50PM: Presentation of Medicen Delegation

- 7PM: Dr Jeff Karp's presentation


- 8PM: Networking

BIO


Dr. Jeff Karp is an Associate Professor at Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Principal Faculty at the Harvard Stem Cell Institute, and affiliate faculty at the Broad Institute and at the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology 

He has published >100 peer-reviewed papers and book chapters and has given >200 national and international invited lectures and has 65 issued or pending patents. Several technologies have formed the foundation for multiple products on the market and currently under development and for the launch of two companies, Gecko Biomedical and Skintifique.

The Boston Business Journal recognized him as a Champion in Healthcare Innovation and MIT’s Technology Review Magazine (TR35) also recognized Dr. Karp as being one of the top innovators in the world (3 members from his laboratory have received this award).

His work has been selected by Popular Mechanic's "Top 20 New Biotech Breakthroughs that Will Change Medicine.” He gave a TEDMED talk on bioinspired medical innovation and is a member of the TEDMED Editorial Advisory Board. In 2015 he received a Breakthrough Award from the Kenneth Rainin Foundation and was a commencement speaker at the University of Toronto.

Dr. Karp was selected as the Outstanding Faculty Undergraduate Mentor among all Faculty at MIT and he received the HST McMahon Mentoring award for being the top mentor of Harvard-MIT students. To date, 17 trainees from his laboratory have secured faculty positions.
results.name: Café Des Sciences Dr Jeff Karp: Simple Innovation Tools for Science and anywhere

results.description:
Livable Cities for the 21st Century -  A Harvard Graduate School of Design Lecture by Jan Gehl

Tuesday, April 12th, 6:30-8pm

Piper Auditorium, Gund Hall, 48 Quincy Street, Cambridge

Free and open to the public. Even link HERE.

:: :: ::

In an important paradigm shift around 1960, urban planning was undertaken at a very large scale in response to the challenges of rapidly growing cities. At the same time, traffic planning began to dominate planning at eye level, to address the rapid influx of cars into cities. The concern for the people using cities that had been maintained over centuries of tradition and experience was completely left behind. The idea of "cities for people" was overlooked and forgotten.

In his lecture, Jan Gehl will summarize this history, which is laid out in his book Cities for People (Island Press, 2010), and go on to explain why looking after people is crucial for the quality of cities in the 21st century; how it can be accomplished; and how it is actually done now in many projects and cities. He will show how, after decades of neglect, "cities for people" is once again a central theme in architecture, urban design, and city planning; and how the transformations carried out by Gehl Architects in Copenhagen, Melbourne, Sydney, New York, Moscow, and other cities exemplify this new people oriented direction in planning.

Jan Gehl began his practice in the early 1960s with a period of research on public space, supported by a grant from his university, which resulted in the book Life Between Buildings (1971). Focusing on the spaces between buildings, he developed an approach to urban design and planning, based on observation of life in public spaces, in particular the assessment and measurement of usage patterns and quality of life.

Gehl is founder and senior advisor of the urban design consultancy Gehl Architects, with expertise in architecture, urban design, and city planning. With members who have backgrounds in architecture, urban design, sociology, anthropology, and cultural theory, the firm has made a name for itself with a holistic, interdisciplinary approach to urban planning that entails not only the application of urban design theory and ideology but also the use of data and analytical strategy. It has undertaken major improvement projects for cities, including Copenhagen, Oslo, Stockholm, Riga, Edinburgh, Perth (WA), Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, Amman, Oman, Cape Town, London, New York and Moscow.

Parallel to his firm’s work, Jan Gehl has authored and coauthored various publications—including New City Life (2006), Cities for People (2010), and How to Study Public Life (2013)—in which he has further developed and shared his techniques of observation and analysis. He has taught at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Copenhagen where, in 1998, he founded the Center for Public Space Research; he has also taught at universities in Edinburgh, Vilnius, Oslo, Toronto, Calgary, Melbourne, Perth, Berkeley, San José, Guadalajara, and Capetown.

Among many honors, Gehl has been awarded the International Union of Architects' Sir Patrick Abercrombie Prize for Exemplary Contributions to Town Planning, as well as honorary doctoral degrees from Universities in Edinburgh and Toronto. He is an honorary fellow of architectural institutes in Denmark, England (RIBA), USA, Canada, and Scotland, as well as the planning Institutes in Australia and Ireland. His work has been the subject of exhibitions at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art (2012) and the Venice Architectural Biennale in 2008, 2012 and 2016.

“First life, then spaces, then buildings – the other way around never works.” ~Jan Gehl

Anyone requiring accessibility accommodations should contact the events office in advance at[masked] or [masked]

results.description:
One-Click Healthcare for 1B+ People. ClickMedix took on the challenge of designing for global health to improve the lives of over 1 billion people using mobile phones in 2007.

BostonCHI is hosting Ting Shih, ClickMedix founder and CEO, to talk about "Designing for Global Health by Personalizing Care Delivery" at IBM Research in Cambridge. While the idea for ClickMedix started at MIT, the real discovery happened when Ting Shih went to test the idea of using mobile phones to deliver health care in sub-Saharan Africa, where there is a lack of doctors, treatments, and over whelming number of patients. To date, ClickMedix has been deployed in 16 countries, in multiple languages and addresses a variety of disease from HIV/AIDS to diabetes. The solution consists of tools for doctors, nurses, health workers, and patients, all “personalized” to the needs of each user. During this session, Ting will share her journey and discovery for designing mobile-phone enabled solutions to deliver personalized care so that each patient can live better, healthier, and happier.

About ClickMedix


ClickMedix is a global mobile health (mHealth) social enterprise founded by faculty and students from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Carnegie Mellon University to increase capacity of physicians and health organizations to serve more patients. By enabling existing medical experts to serve more patients, we can address the following global healthcare challenges:

• Lack of access: Patients cannot easily reach doctors.

• Lack of funds: Patients cannot afford the high cost of healthcare, and governments/NGOs are unable to subsidize underserved-populations entirely.

• Lack of medical resources: Most countries face severe shortages of trained healthcare professionals, especially medical experts.

Our Mission is to bring affordable and quality health services to under-served patients, by enabling health organizations to reach more patients through mobile phone/tablet facilitated remote diagnosis, as well as remote training and supervision of their staff assistants, nurses, and health workers.

About Ting

“Globally, most people have a mobile phone, some even before they have electricity, so why not use mobile phones to deliver healthcare so that everyone can access healthcare with a Click?” As the founder of ClickMedix, Ting uses her decade of experience in designing and launching technology services, along with associated business strategies for US government, pharmaceutical and global education organizations, to build ClickMedix from an idea in an MIT classroom to a global enterprise. Her areas of expertise include innovation strategy, product development, lean/Six Sigma process improvement, operations management, organization change management, and business development.

She spent three years as a founder of Click Diagnostics, a social enterprise born out of the MIT Media Lab, conducting mobile health projects and pilots in over ten countries in Africa, South Asia, the Middle East, and North America. She was integral to designing mobile health systems that can withstand unreliable or intermittent mobile network, while satisfying the varied needs of healthcare in underserved communities. She founded ClickMedix to build upon the success and learning from the three-year pilot of creating a highly reliable, secure, and user-friendly, HIPAA-compliant telehealth, disease management, and care coordination system that can be deployed quickly to health practitioners and connect patients with medical experts worldwide. Ting leads the design, development, and deployment efforts for ClickMedix’s affordable mobile health and education system.

Ting is named Toyota Mothers of Invention in 2015 and Cartier Women’s Initiative Awards Laureate in 2012 for North America. She is also an industry advisor/contributing writer for Telemedicine Magazine. She holds an MBA from the MIT Sloan School of Management and MS in Systems Engineering from MIT, as an MIT Leaders for Global Operations Fellow and Public Service Fellow. In addition, she holds a BS in Computer Science and MS in Software Design and Management from Carnegie Mellon University.

About BostonCHI

BostonCHI is the Boston chapter of ACM's special interest group on Computer Human Interaction (CHI). Event Schedule

6:30 – 7:00 Networking over pizza and beverages
7:00 – 8:30 Meeting
8:30 – 9:00 CHI Dessert and more networking!

Monthly Sponsors

Thank you to our generous sponsors. Interested in sponsoring BostonCHI? Let us know!

IBM Research is hosting us and providing food.

VitaminT is sponsoring dessert.

results.description:
Adventure in the Arctic, Svalbard Archipelago - Potluck & Slideshow

Potluck 6:30pm, Slideshow 7:15pm


Svalbard, a Norwegian archipelago only 600 miles from the North Pole, is an area of amazing beauty.  Snow capped mountains, magnificent fjords, and massive glaciers provide stunning scenery unlike any other part of the world--except Antarctica. Add to that frequent sightings of polar bears, reindeers, walruses, seals, puffins, and terns; as well as cliffs with thousands of auks, guillemots and kittiwakes; and you end up with an unforgettable experience.  Come see photographs and hear story of a trip that Ashok made to this remote area in the Arctic. He is an award-winning photographer who has previously shared his travel experience in Ladakh.

Potluck Info: Participation in the potlucks is optional, yet useful for that  post-office work hunger. Homemade dishes are welcome, store bought goodies & takeout are equally welcome. Plates, bowls, cups, cutlery, napkins and drink pitchers will be supplied. The auditorium has a kitchen if you need to do any re-warming or prep (stovetop, oven, microwave, sink & fridge). Please bring your own cooking pots if needed for stovetop. Potlucks start at 6:30pm.

Subway Directions: Take the MBTA Red or Green Line to Park Street Station. Walk through the Boston Common uphill towards the State House on Beacon St. To the left of the State House is Joy St; follow Joy St uphill to the AMC Auditorium Building (brownstone), #4 Joy St on the left hand side. Map: http://tinyurl.com/4JoyStMap

Parking: Nearby parking is available at the Boston Common Garage, located underneath the Boston Common. Access is off Charles St, between the Public Garden and the Boston Common. We sell discount parking passes  ($9 each). You'll save 50%! More info about the Garage is here:  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/boston-boston-common-garage-zero-charles-street-parking.html#Tab_coupon-rates

results.description:
INSPIRING SOLUTIONS FOR DIFFICULT TIMES                                                                                                     a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | MARCH 22nd - APRIL 26th


7:00 - 8:30pm

Sometimes life can become overwhelming with difficult and turbulent events. At such times, peace can feel far away. However, just as the center of a hurricane is perfectly still, through meditation we can learn to build a place of peace within. From this inner space, we can make good decisions that foster harmony and happiness for ourself and others.

Join us in this practical course to learn simple and effective meditations for becoming more peaceful and at ease in everyday life. By creating peace within, we can share this with our community, our city and our world. Each class is beginner friendly- feel free to drop-in to any class in the series or try to attend each one!

Feel free to drop-in to any or all of the meditation classes in this series! No need to pre-register. 

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis


Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE!

results.description:
We'll discuss our ideas about what are the evolutionary benefits of religious belief.

A belief in religion is clearly common across most societies, so it must have provided benefit to those societies. Perhaps it facilitated the development of social cohesion. Researchers at Oxford University found that "Humans are naturally inclined to believe in gods and an afterlife," but they also "discovered that people living in cities in thriving countries with strong social networks were less likely to follow religion."  

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1386533/Belief-religion-simply-universal-human-nature.html

results.description:
click to purchase ticket Ticket required to reserve a spot 

Y'know how you can be at a singles event with amazing people and you got your eye on someone and he/she is occupied with someone else ALL NIGHT. Bummer! You don't want to be rude and butt in but jeez! Or maybe you’re enjoying yourself with a friend and you don’t want to make that effort to try to edge into various conversations to meet the folks there. 

AND that awkward moment of KNOWING its not a match and wanting to squirm out of that conversation. And the other person WANTS YOU TO STAY! 

Well we’ll take care of that for you!!! 
SO… it will be just a mix and mingle for most of it. But in the beginning there will be some activities (ice breaker kinds of games) to help you meet everyone there, just to see if there is a click and see if you want to talk with them later.  So you just get to relax and enjoy and meet people and we'll take care of some of that awkwardness for you. 

It will be just a fun event with wine and cheese and stuff and nice music playing in the background in a VERY cool loft. People have been loving these events. And we’ll keep doing it till we want to stop :) Its pretty unique. It takes a bit of courage to give it a shot but I really think you won’t regret it at all :)

Click here to purchase a ticket

Testimonials

"Jon's singles events are relaxed, stimulating and they work!  Last one I went to had 15 women, all different than the ones who were at his previous month’s event.  I liked 3 women, they liked me, our contact info was exchanged by a third party, and they all want to get together!  That’s a successful evening.  Thank you Jon! "  - Erick 

Thank you to you and Katie for a warm & entertaining event! It was a fun evening and fostered personal growth and new connections. Looking forward to future events.-Aimee P

Wow. That was *fantastic*. The activities (and the wine) made meeting lots of interesting people really easy and a huge amount of fun. And the loft gallery location was perfect. I would definitely do it again. Thanks Jon, Katie and Abby!- Matt

I had a great time John and Katie were excellent host's. It was fun and a learning curve for me. There were a lot of great Singles there. The nicest thing was you never felt uncomfortable with anyone. I would recommend this to anyone jumping back into the dating scene. - Howard

That was a wonderful evening - fun, engaging. Definitely a success. Much more interaction than a typical speed dating event. Katie and Jon - nice job combining interesting activities, a great space and tasty food -Karen

results.description:
Next up is The Encyclopedia of Early Earth, by Isabel Greenberg.

I am somewhat intrigued.

Logistical Stuff: The location is TBD! Supposedly the Friendly Toast is doing trivia on Tuesdays in general now, which is a bit of a problem for us. Joseph sent me an email with location ideas that I haven't picked through yet, but if anyone else has ideas please let me know!

The Bumf:

Before our history began, another--now forgotten--civilization thrived. The people who roamed Early Earth were much like us: curious, emotional, funny, ambitious, and vulnerable. In this series of illustrated and linked tales, Isabel Greenberg chronicles the explorations of a young man as he paddles from his home in the North Pole to the South Pole. There, he meets his true love, but their romance is ill-fated. Early Earth's unusual and finicky polarity means the lovers can never touch.


If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!


If you're running late, please post a comment on the page for this meetup; in order to get a table at the Friendly Toast, we need to tell them how many people we have, so if you aren't there and you don't let us know what's up, we may not have space for you!


For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!
results.name: The Encyclopedia of Early Earth by Isabel Greenberg

results.description:
Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:00pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:20pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.
results.name: Weekly Hack Night

results.description:
(NOTE:  This class is the next level of the How To Clear Your Energy Field and Setting Good Boundaries Classes.  They are not pre-requisites, but you'll learn a deeper level of the work we started in those programs.)


Do you sometimes feel like you're under attack?

Do you find yourself exhausted for no reason sometimes?

Do some people just wear you down with their demanding ways or neediness?

Then a class on Shielding is exactly what you need.

Shields are a much-misunderstood subject. People think of them as being like a Star Trek force field or a wall of violet flame. And they can be. But if you try to live behind one of those type shields, you'll find yourself feeling cut off, isolated, and lonely very quickly.

The art to shield design is a rich and varied model. In this class, we'll design and set in place permanent shields (which you can change anytime you want - you're setting them, not me).

You'll Learn:

• What you must master first before your shields will work

• What the two different kinds of shields are and when to use them

• The different elements of shield design and how to choose what you want

• The pitfalls of shield design that most people fall into that make the shields unsustainable and easily breached

By the end of class, you'll have set up a shield for yourself using the techniques taught in class and you'll be able to use the perspectives on shield design to add infinite levels and layers to your shielding.

PLEASE ARRIVE 10-15 MINUTES EARLY! Doors close at 7:00pm - When people trickle in, the class loses focus and momentum. We will start promptly at 7pm. Be on time or you risk being locked out. If you are detained due to an emergency, please text me at[masked]

We're limited to 15 people in this class space and our classes tend to sell out well in advance of the class time, so don't wait to register. Parking is easily available on the street both at meters and with a parking pass (we have 2 - first come first served). Yes, you'll need a pass unlike on Sundays when it's open parking. We're also just a half mile walk from the Porter T stop and the 83 and 87 buses stop at the bottom of our street, so we're easily accessible.

PLEASE Do Not Wear Fragrances! Kelle is extremely allergic to them (yes, even essential oils) and you will be asked to leave if your body spray, cologne, perfume, etc. sets off her allergies. Litmus test: if other people who aren't hugging you say "wow, you smell nice!" it's too much scent for Kelle to tolerate.
results.name: Setting Shields - The Art of Self-Protection

results.description:
Learn Afro Cuban movement, Rumba (dance & percussion), Casino, Rueda De Casino and more with MetaMovements! Our instructors have all trained in Cuba and are excited to share their knowledge with you! Don't miss out on our Spring session of this fun AND affordable program!

Join us on Tuesdays or Sundays OR BOTH!
Special discount applies to those who participate on both days!

DATES:
April 12th- May 31st, 2016

(TUES) Training Group ONLY: Tuesdays, 7-9 pm
Finally get that Cuban flavor you've been looking for by training in popular and traditional Cuban dance. With this you can learn the secrets of Afro-Cuban movements and techniques and add some SABOR to your movement! Available for both beginners and intermediate/advanced dancers.

(TUES & SUN)Performance & Training Group: Tuesdays 7-9pm & Sundays 12:30-3:30pm


COST:

Tuesday (2 hrs) training - $145 for 8 week session
(Cost includes Tuesday nights, and access to our group archive, as well as other group opportunities)

• Sunday (2.5 hrs) training/practice - $145 for 8 week session

• BOTH Tuesday & Sundays - $195 for 8 week session                                          $195 for NEW students (Cost includes all Training Group benefits, plus Sunday rehearsals & bootcamps, access to video training, and a group T-shirt)

Apply today if you are interested here:
http://goo.gl/forms/G83tzJpMel
(If you are currently in the program, please do not complete this application form - please sign up with Kaitlin Nancy)

MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PROGRAM:

MetaMovements Latin Dance Company's Cubanízate Bi-National Training and Performance Program explores several styles of traditional and popular dances born in Cuba, including Rumba, Son, Casino, Afro-Cuban and Rueda de Casino. Connect to the music, your partner and the history in a whole new way! Give us two months, and you will see and feel the difference with that special Cuban energy will be flowing through you !

Cubanizate! is a one-of-a-kind program in which dancers from Cuba & the US train simultaneously-opening the doors for cultural exchange and community-building across borders in a way that’s never happened before. Experience this program in which students and instructors in both countries share their knowledge and culture, providing exceptional learning opportunities for all involved. Join us to support Cuban artists in their goal of connecting with the rest of the world in a way they have not been able to in the past and gain skills and movement that you had never imagined possible!

Finally get that Cuban flavor you've been looking for by training in popular and traditional Cuban dance. With this you can learn the secrets of Afro-Cuban movements and techniques and add some SABOR to your movement! Available for both beginners and intermediate/advanced dancers. ALSO… Want to travel to Cuba with MetaMovements and DANCE?

As an added benefit of the Cubanizate program, receive training and performance opportunities in Cuba PLUS free training session with choreographers from Danza Chévere! There's more: a $100 discount on a group program with MetaMovements Latin Dance Company to Cuba for all Cubanizate members!

Sign up for the Cubanizate Bi-National Program by completing this application form: http://goo.gl/forms/G83tzJpMel If you have any questions, feel free to contact us at [masked] or by calling[masked]

results.description:
Though we might wish we could, we can't always think of everything ourselves. Join Danny and other writers for a chance to engage your writing with a community and get the kind of new, original feedback that gets the writing juices flowing. Before every meeting we'll each submit a short story, section of a novel or other work to be reviewed (up to 10-12 double spaced pages or[masked] words*). Come prepared to give written and verbal feedback on others' work as well as receive feedback on your own. Open to all, but limited to 5 each session (plus organizers) on a first come first serve basis.

Please RSVP and be prepared to submit your work about a week before we meet to give everyone a chance to read. RSVPs will close a few days before the event.

Submissions are hosted on a shared Box.com folder, which requires an email address to access.  If this is your first time joining, let Danny know your preferred email address and he will invite you.

Monthly
Cost is $15

Led by Danny Shain

Danny graduated from Union College with a degree in English, and has spent years working as a copy-editor, freelance writer and blogger.  A follower of technology trends whose reading interests range from the fantastical to the contemporary to the philosophical, Danny is excited to help people refine their writing, express themselves, and build a writing community through this workshop.

*Note: If you'd like to include slightly more than 10-12 pages to provide some context (ie: your chapter ends 1-2 pages later) that's ok, but please indicate which pages you'd like critiqued. Pages beyond that should be submitted as an optional read.

results.description:
An evening of meditation practice, led by Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie, Senior Minister. Sessions include seated & walking meditation, Dharma talk, and conversation.  This practice is open to all, beginning and experience practitioners.


The warm, inviting evening includes two short seated meditations; walking meditation through the gorgeous Arlington Street Church sanctuary and Public Garden; and community discussion.


Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie is an extraordinary and inspired leader in the LGBTQ community.  She is founder of The Shared Heart, a traveling exhibition and book of photographs of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender teenagers, designed to support the Massachusetts Safe Schools Initiative.  The Legacy Foundation named Rev. Crawford Harvie Uncommon Woman of the Year.  The Women's Educational and Industrial Union of Boston honored her as one of 100 outstanding women in the Commonwealth.  She is recipient of the Maximilian Kolbe Award for Community Service and was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year.  In 2004, she performed the first same-sex wedding in a church in the United States.  

Rev. Kim has been a Zen Buddhist practitioner since 1977.

For more information on the evening:  Arlington Street Zen Center


Prior to the ASZC at 7:00 pm, you are also warmly invited to join the Buddha's Belly Book Group at 6:00 pm in the Hunnewell Chapel.  Check out the ASC website for information on what book the Buddhas Belly group is currently reading.
results.how_to_find_us: Hunnewell Chapel (enter on Boylston Street)

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 4/12 Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
Shamanic Journeying is a tool that has been traditionally used by indigenous shamans for the healing of individuals and communities. Shamans use drums and rattles to shift their consciousness into non-ordinary reality, a trance-like state, to communicate with their helping guides and spirits. We know now that anyone can learn to journey, to connect with their own helping guides and spirits in non- ordinary reality, in order to get answers to personal questions, solve problems, open creativity, see new ways of being in the world and obtain healing information for themselves and their community. Each participate will receive a Shamanic Blessings from Sue.

Please bring something for the alter, a journal and anything you would need to lay down with.

CALL, EMAIL OR TEXT Sue for information and registration:
[masked]
[masked]

Date: 

Every 2nd and 4th Tuesday of each month

Time: 7pm to 8 pm

Cost: $35

 Angelo created Shamanic Spirit Song over the past 10 years blending her natural intuitive gifts with her training as a Shamanic and Energy practitioner. Sue studies and practices Native America, Peruvian, and West Africa Traditions of Shamanism. She is certified by the Rhys Thomas Institute of Energy Medicine and is a certified Reiki Master. She worked in women’s health care for 30 years.
