results.description:
Ticket required to reserve a spot. This meetup posted on multiple groups.  Guys use code 50Percent for 1/2 off 

Have Fun. Drink Wine. Meet People

Guys, read this from another guy who has been to a few of these events:

"Jon's singles events are relaxed, stimulating and they work!  Last one I went to had 15 women, all different than the ones who were at his previous month’s event.  I liked 3 women, they liked me, our contact info was exchanged by a third party, and they all want to get together!  That’s a successful evening.  Thank you Jon!"    - Eric

'Nuf said

Click here to purchase a ticket


Wow. That was *fantastic*. The activities (and the wine) made meeting lots of interesting people really easy and a huge amount of fun. And the loft gallery location was perfect. I would definitely do it again. Thanks Jon, Katie and Abby!- Matt

I had a great time John and Katie were excellent host's. It was fun and a learning curve for me. There were a lot of great Singles there. The nicest thing was you never felt uncomfortable with anyone. I would recommend this to anyone jumping back into the dating scene. - Howard


Y'know how you can be at a singles event with amazing people and you got your eye on someone and he/she is occupied with someone else ALL NIGHT. Bummer! You don't want to be rude and butt in but jeez! Or maybe you’re enjoying yourself with a friend and you don’t want to make that effort to try to edge into various conversations to meet the folks there. 

AND that awkward moment of KNOWING its not a match and wanting to squirm out of that conversation. And the other person WANTS YOU TO STAY! 

Well we’ll take care of that for you!!! 
SO… it will be just a mix and mingle for most of it. But in the beginning there will be some activities (ice breaker kinds of games) to help you meet everyone there, just to see if there is a click and see if you want to talk with them later.  So you just get to relax and enjoy and meet people and we'll take care of some of that awkwardness for you. 

It will be just a fun event with wine and cheese and stuff and nice music playing in the background in a VERY cool loft. People have been loving these events. And we’ll keep doing it till we want to stop :) Its pretty unique. It takes a bit of courage to give it a shot but I really think you won’t regret it at all :)

Click here to purchase a ticket

Testimonials

"Jon's singles events are relaxed, stimulating and they work!  Last one I went to had 15 women, all different than the ones who were at his previous month’s event.  I liked 3 women, they liked me, our contact info was exchanged by a third party, and they all want to get together!  That’s a successful evening.  Thank you Jon! "  - Erick 

Thank you to you and Katie for a warm & entertaining event! It was a fun evening and fostered personal growth and new connections. Looking forward to future events.-Aimee P

Wow. That was *fantastic*. The activities (and the wine) made meeting lots of interesting people really easy and a huge amount of fun. And the loft gallery location was perfect. I would definitely do it again. Thanks Jon, Katie and Abby!- Matt

I had a great time John and Katie were excellent host's. It was fun and a learning curve for me. There were a lot of great Singles there. The nicest thing was you never felt uncomfortable with anyone. I would recommend this to anyone jumping back into the dating scene. - Howard

That was a wonderful evening - fun, engaging. Definitely a success. Much more interaction than a typical speed dating event. Katie and Jon - nice job combining interesting activities, a great space and tasty food -Karen

results.description:
This Reiki Share is for you if you have been attuned as a Reiki Practitioner it is a powerful group Reiki session for all level Reiki Practitioners. A safe, supportive, nurturing and positive space is created for us to develop, practice and give back Reiki with like-minded friends. It is a great time to give yourself a tune-up and relish in Reiki.  Each practitioner will have the opportunity to give and receive Reiki during this relaxation and rejuvenating Reiki Share. Contact me if you have questions.

  Reiki Share Agenda

• The 1st 15 minutes of each share we will have time to connect with friends and introduce new members, allowing time to center and prepare for our Reiki sessions.

• It is our goal that each practitioner will have the opportunity to relish in 20 to 30 minutes of Reiki; dependent on how many practitioners are present for the share. 

• We will make every effort to synchronize each session allowing for the highest healing good of each person.

• Quiet discussion of the sessions may be shared quietly while your group is preparing for the next person.

• The room will be available at the conclusion of the Reiki Share so that you can socialize, give feedback and network with like-minded friends.

  Reiki Share Guidelines

• RSVP so that we may plan for adequate space and tables.

• Arrive on time, this allows time to center and enjoy the evening in a stress free manner.

• Please silence or turn off cell/mobile phones.

• During the share please be respectful of other groups enjoying Reiki by keeping conversations to a whisper and as brief as possible.  There will be ample time at the end of the evening for comments and discussions.

• If arriving late to the share, please enter the room "quietly" so the active session is not disturbed.  You may spend time in quite mediation, preparing for Reiki or enjoying self Reiki joining a group when the monument presents itself.  

Donations will be collected to offset the cost of the room.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Payment in advance is preferred, but you can pay when you arrive if necessary. Go here to pay in advanceand don't forget to RSVP here on Meetup too.

Come, enjoy and learn many permaculture techniques, plant id, plant care, harvesting and processing practices while socializing with other like-minded gardeners. Work with permaculture gardeners Debby and Lillabeth and go home with new knowledge and samples from the garden.

About iFarm: ifarm utilizes a restored 19th century farmstead to reconnect the individual with the earth. The goal is to provide diverse educational experiences that utilize core values of sustainability, rejuvenation, and thoughtful design which both individuals and communities can incorporate into their own environment, experiences and life.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

results.description:
You may not know it, but the original parcel of land that founded the Audobon Society is not even one block off Beacon Street, right where Brookline and Boston meet. That piece of land is kept wild and free, and even though it’s small, you can find a bountiful variety of birds there – and wild medicinal plants!

The ability to identify and use each of these plants was once commonplace to every man, woman, and child, but today most of us have lost that knowledge. Come reclaim what’s yours!

Join us regularly throughout the growing seasons and learn the plants in all of their stages of growth. By the end of these sessions, you’ll feel confident in your ability to identify the many medicinal plants growing right in the middle of the city – and you’ll learn how you can work with them!

Wednesday, April 13th, 2016
5:30 – 6:30pm
Hall’s Pond Sanctuary, Brookline MA 02446

Meet at the gate near the tennis courts, just off Beacon Street near the Hawes Street T stop. We’ll get started right at 5:30 and wrap up by 6:30. Feel free to bring a notebook or sketchbook, cameras, etc. The fee for the herb walk is $5.

Herb walks are “Sprinkle or Shine!” – if it’s just damp or a bit drizzly, we’ll walk anyway. If it’s raining enough to need an umbrella, that makes it hard to learn, so we will cancel in that event.

Interested in having us come and do an herb walk somewhere in particular? Let us know!
results.name: Herb Walk at Hall's Pond, Brookline

See the power of combining these powerful and relaxing modalities!

Speaker Chris Vasiliadis, M.Ed., Certified Health and Wellness Coach will speak to us "Set the Stage for Increased Energy and Vitality"
Today’s world is hyper-busy, with many of us possessing multiple “hats”/roles in our lives. Do you find yourself more overwhelmed and scattered instead of focused on what’s important? Stressed more frequently than grounded and calm? Exhausted more often than energized? Is there some weight you’d like to lose?
You can turn your situation around! In this talk, begin to take a stand for the level of well-being you want. You will come away with breakthrough insights and practical actions you can take immediately to start taking control of your health and wellness.
As a result of attending this talk, you will:
- Devise a compelling vision of your desired level of well-being
- Recognize the power of managing energy over time
- Identify energy drains and jump-starts
- Pinpoint essential elements for you to succeed
Come network with the best business women on the north shore!

A seasoned investor in Canada and several entrepreneurs will lead the discussion. Panelists include:

• Raj Melville, Executive Director, Deshpande Foundation (Includes the Pond Deshpande Center for Innovation and Entepreneurship at the University of New Brunswick, Canada) 

• Dr. John LaBrie, Dean of the College of Professional Studies, Northeastern University

• Monica Brady-Myerov, Founder & CEO, Listen Current

• Liam Pisano, Managing Director, LearnLaunch

The CENE is a non-profit member driven organization that is dedicated to supporting Canadian technology and life science entrepreneurship.

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

BARBERSHOP: THE NEXT CUT
Release Date:

April 15, 2016
Rating:

PG-13

Synopsis:

It’s been more than 10 years since our last appointment at Calvin’s Barbershop. Calvin (Ice Cube) and his longtime crew, including Eddie (Cedric the Entertainer), are still there, but the shop has undergone some major changes. Most noticeably, our once male-dominated sanctuary is now co-ed. The ladies bring their own flavor, drama and gossip to the shop challenging the fellas at every turn. Despite the good times and camaraderie within the shop, the surrounding community has taken a turn for the worse, forcing Calvin and our crew to come together to not only save the shop, but their neighborhood.

results.description:
6:00 - 7:00 Networking, Introductions, Food and Refreshments

7:00 - 7:45 Data reduction for Hybrid Cloud

Does your data center have ENOUGH storage? What could you do if you could get more space without having to purchase more equipment?  That’s the promise of data reduction technology.

This session will cover approaches to delivering data reduction available today. Data reduction cuts $/GB costs, reduces storage footprint, and helps you deliver affordable storage performance. You will leave this session understanding the benefits of inline data reduction software for Linux.

The session will conclude with a live demonstration of data reduction software for Linux. Permabit will show how their software can be deployed in repeatable IT infrastructures to realize greater than 50% savings for general computing and archive environments. 

Speaker Bio: Devon Yablonski, Senior Systems Engineer. 

Devon is responsible for technical sales and systems engineering of Permabit's data reduction product portfolio with duties including solution architecture and evaluation, performance, installation and support.  He has been an integral part of product design and prototyping of several Permabit data efficiency products. 
Devon is experienced with all flash and hybrid arrays, server and desktop virtualization, and open computing including OpenStack, RedHat Ceph, ZFS and others. He possesses technical competencies in high performance and resource efficiency technologies in storage, and processor microarchitecture. Previous to Permabit, Devon was a performance expert and Product Manager in Intel, PPC and NVIDIA based radar and signal processing for Mercury Systems in Chelmsford, MA, studied GPGPU acceleration of medical algorithms at Northeastern University and was an embedded firmware engineer at Zebra Technologies in Lincoln, RI.

Devon holds a Master's degree in Computer & Electrical Engineering from Northeastern University and a Master's of Business Administration from Boston College.  

8:00 - 8:45 Network Monitoring Best Practices 

Virtualizing systems without knowing their usual CPU/Memory load, disk usage and network usage is risky! With a virtual monitor you can analyze your system prior to virtualization in order to know how much load it will put on your Host servers. Systems with high load may not be suitable for virtualization at all. 

Join Paessler, the creators of PRTG Network Monitor and Paessler's Sales Engineer, Greg Ross, for a live session where they will discuss network monitoring best practices and how you can use PRTG Network Monitor to set up a world-class monitoring strategy for your organization. 

Speaker Bio: Greg Ross, Sales Engineer 

Greg is responsible for technical presales and systems engineering of Paessler’s PRTG Network Monitor with a focus on system architecture, scalability, performance, installation and support.

He brings over 15 years of technical experience in the publishing, retail, high tech and online recruitment industries.  Before coming on board with Paessler his experience included system administration roles at EMC, Monster Worldwide and Brookstone.

Greg holds an MBA from Rivier College, a B.A. in Theology and Philosophy from Geneva College and multiple certifications from industry leading organizations including Microsoft, Cisco, EMC, and CompTIA.

8:45 - Evaluations and raffle prizes
results.name: Data Reduction for Hybrid Cloud and Best Practices in Network Monitoring

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
6:00 - 6:30 PM - Networking

6:30 - 8:00 PM - Talk; Q&A

•                     Title, Abstract & About Author 

Data Mining Mining Data: The Challenge Behind Supply Chain Data

Every day we hear about supply chain devastated by problems ranging from sweatshops to super storms. One major problem is that supply chains have never been mapped - and it's impossible for corporations, NGO's or governments to keep track of any problems before they happen. We'll explore how supply chain data is stored across thousands of databases around the world, and how we can collect and analyze the data. 

Leonardo Bonanni, PhD is an entrepreneur, a scholar and an advocate for supply chain transparency: in 2011 Dr. Bonanni founded Sourcemap Inc., the first supply chain mapping company; he has taught sustainability at MIT, Parsons, Columbia University and NYU, and he has been named among American’s ‘Most Influential People in Business Ethics’ and ‘Most Promising Social Entrepreneurs.’ He holds a PhD from the MIT Media Lab and has a background in engineering and design.
results.name: Data Mining Mining Data: the Challenge Behind Supply Chain Data

results.description:
Hey BUG! Join us with Trevor Stricker, of Disco Pixel, as he shares valuable lessons learned with Unity's new GUI system! Our host Akamai will once again be sponsoring pizza, beverages and the venue! Please RSVP to ensure enough food for all!


So what's this about new GUI? Canvases, RectTransforms, and Layouts! Oh my! Unity has ditched OnGUI and come a long way towards the engine understanding that displays have different aspect ratios and pixel densities. But when your game logic wants to fill a scrollable list with inventory items, then your code needs to work with the GUI. What the editor shows in a RectTransform is totally different from the member variables. Layouts seem to love doing exactly the wrong thing without giving any warning about bogus values. The wrong things often end up drawing on top. This talk will delve into programming useful and slick GUI behavior into Unity’s new GUI system.


Trevor started making games on the Dreamcast when games came on disks and people read about them in magazines printed on dead trees. He spent a decade making console games like NBA 2K and Panzer Dragoon Orta in roles from coffee fetcher to designer to lead programmer. He went indie in 2008, way before it was mainstream. He was in charge of development for Quickhit NFL Football, an early F2P online game that raised VC, signed the NFL, and sold to a publisher. After that he founded Disco Pixel where his love of rhythm games drummed up Jungle Rumble. It recently launched on PlayStation Vita and iOS, where it rose to the top of the music game charts in countries from the US to the Netherlands to Japan.


***********************************

Please RSVP so we can ensure enough food and drinks for the attendees! 

Our Sponsors:

Thanks to our sponsors! Unity and Akamai are generously sponsoring our meetup again this month. 

See you there! 
- B.U.G.
results.name: uGUI Programming: Buttoning Up Unity in Code

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

This week we will be discussing how trading fits within ones long term goals and some high level approaches to it. 

Any new members will have the chance to introduce themselves state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

-------------------- 

This meeting is FREE and it repeats on the 2nd Wednesday of every month.

results.description:
Come join me explore the history of Fashion through 3 unique exhibits

#techstyle

March 6, 2016 – July 10, 2016
Henry and Lois Foster Gallery (Gallery 158)

Above: Designed by Iris van Herpen and Neri Oxman, printed by Stratasys, Anthozoa Cape and Skirt, Voltage Haute Couture Collection, 2013. Object Connex multiple-materials; 3-D printed. Museum purchase with funds donated by the Fashion Council. © M. Zoeter x Iris van Herpen. Photography by Ronald Stoops.Clothes that respond to the environment, are ingeniously constructed from recycled materials, and garments that come off a 3-D printer ready to wear—all of these innovations are poised to have a profound impact on the future of the fashion industry. Designers have embraced these innovations and “#techstyle” explores how the synergy between fashion and technology is not only changing the way designers design, but also the way people interact with their clothing. The exhibition draws on the MFA’s collection of contemporary fashion and accessories, and features key pieces from innovators in the field including a digitally-printed dress from Alexander McQueen’s Plato’s Atlantis collection (Spring/Summer 2010/2011) and Iris van Herpen’s 3-D printed dress (2013) produced in collaboration with MIT designer and assistant professor Neri Oxman. Visitors experience the cutting edge of hi-tech fashion with special commissions created by CuteCircuit, Hussein Chalayan, Kate Goldsworthy, and Somerville-based Nervous System.


http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/banner_grid-9_retina/s3/IMG_1691Editbewerkt_4x3_0.jpg?itok=AstQcm_z

Hiro
Photographs

December 12, 2015 – August 14, 2016
Herb Ritts Gallery (Gallery 169)

Hiro (born in 1930) is known for his distinctively conceived and precisely realized images across a range of subjects including fashion, portraiture, and still life. Born Yasuhiro Wakabayashi in Shanghai to Japanese parents, he grew up in China and spent the years following WWII in Japan before coming to the US in 1954. Early in his career, Hiro worked as an assistant for the celebrated photographer Richard Avedon who, upon recognizing Hiro’s talents, introduced him to Alexey Brodovitch, the legendary art director of Harper’s Bazaar. By the early 1960s Hiro had become a widely admired figure in the field. His work was known for its originality and technical innovation, with bold uses of light and color, and an elegant sense of surrealism. This exhibition focuses on a selection of Hiro’s fashion images that demonstrate how he applied his unique visual aesthetic to the work of fashion and jewelry designers such as Halston, Pierre Cardin, Harry Winston, and Elsa Peretti, among others. This will be the first solo exhibition of Hiro’s work to be held in a major American museum.


Kenneth Paul Block illustrations

December 12, 2015 – August 14, 2016
Clementine Brown Gallery (Gallery 170)

http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/banner_grid-9_retina/s3/SC236167_4x3.jpg?itok=KiuEpmga

Kenneth Paul Block (1925–2009) is arguably the most important fashion illustrator of the second half of the 20th century. His versatility and ability to create a graceful gesture or evoke the high energy of the post–WWII generation make his work stand out among illustrators of his time. Throughout his career, mainly with Women’s Wear Daily and W Magazine, he chronicled fashionable designs and the lifestyles of the people who wore them. Blending illustration and portraiture, his drawings of figures like Jacqueline Kennedy, Babe Paley and Gloria Guinness capture the sophistication of the era’s socialites and celebrities. This chronological survey contains approximately 30 works spanning Block’s career from the 1950s into the 1990s––drawing from the MFA’s repository of Block’s extensive archive of drawings. Including examples of fashion illustrations and society portraits, works range from early black-and-white drawings in charcoal to later works in watercolor and colored pencil.

Above: Kenneth Paul Block, Eight female models in fall coats from different French fashion houses, March 4–11, 1991. Watercolor and charcoal on watercolor board. Gift of Kenneth Paul Block, made possible with the generous assistance of Jean S. and Frederic A. Sharf. Block / WWD / Condé Nast Archives. Copyright © Condé Nast.
results.name: MFA Free Wednesday Fashion

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

results.description:
6:00 - 7:00 Networking, Introductions, Food and Refreshments

7:00 - 7:45 Data reduction for Hybrid Cloud

Does your data center have ENOUGH storage? What could you do if you could get more space without having to purchase more equipment?  That’s the promise of data reduction technology.

This session will cover approaches to delivering data reduction available today. Data reduction cuts $/GB costs, reduces storage footprint, and helps you deliver affordable storage performance. You will leave this session understanding the benefits of inline data reduction software for Linux.

The session will conclude with a live demonstration of data reduction software for Linux. Permabit will show how their software can be deployed in repeatable IT infrastructures to realize greater than 50% savings for general computing and archive environments.

Speaker Bio: Devon Yablonski, Senior Systems Engineer. 

Devon is responsible for technical sales and systems engineering of Permabit's data reduction product portfolio with duties including solution architecture and evaluation, performance, installation and support.  He has been an integral part of product design and prototyping of several Permabit data efficiency products. 
Devon is experienced with all flash and hybrid arrays, server and desktop virtualization, and open computing including OpenStack, RedHat Ceph, ZFS and others. He possesses technical competencies in high performance and resource efficiency technologies in storage, and processor microarchitecture. Previous to Permabit, Devon was a performance expert and Product Manager in Intel, PPC and NVIDIA based radar and signal processing for Mercury Systems in Chelmsford, MA, studied GPGPU acceleration of medical algorithms at Northeastern University and was an embedded firmware engineer at Zebra Technologies in Lincoln, RI.

Devon holds a Master's degree in Computer & Electrical Engineering from Northeastern University and a Master's of Business Administration from Boston College.  

8:00 - 8:45 Network Monitoring Best Practices 

Virtualizing systems without knowing their usual CPU/Memory load, disk usage and network usage is risky! With a virtual monitor you can analyze your system prior to virtualization in order to know how much load it will put on your Host servers. Systems with high load may not be suitable for virtualization at all.  

Join Paessler, the creators of PRTG Network Monitor and Paessler's Sales Engineer, Greg Ross, for a live session where they will discuss network monitoring best practices and how you can use PRTG Network Monitor to set up a world-class monitoring strategy for your organization.

Speaker Bio: Greg Ross, Sales Engineer


Greg is responsible for technical presales and systems engineering of Paessler’s PRTG Network Monitor with a focus on system architecture, scalability, performance, installation and support.

He brings over 15 years of technical experience in the publishing, retail, high tech and online recruitment industries.  Before coming on board with Paessler his experience included system administration roles at EMC, Monster Worldwide and Brookstone.

Greg holds an MBA from Rivier College, a B.A. in Theology and Philosophy from Geneva College and multiple certifications from industry leading organizations including Microsoft, Cisco, EMC, and CompTIA.

8:45 - Evaluations and raffle prizes
results.name: Data Reduction for Hybrid Cloud and        Best Practices in Network Monitoring

results.description:
The Microsoft Azure cloud platform offers a service called Azure SQL Database. How does this compare to SQL Server, the venerable boxed product so many DBAs have come to know and love? In this talk from long-time Azure MVP Bill Wilder, we will look at similarities and differences. We will also briefly talk about complementary data storage sources that may also interest DBAs. At the end of the talk, you will understand the big picture of database options in the cloud, how Azure SQL Database is positioned and stacks up relative to SQL, and leave with an appreciation of key scenarios where it might make sense to use one over the other.

 Bill Wilder is a cloud computing veteran, with deep expertise in the Microsoft Azure cloud platform. Since 2014, Bill has been CTO at Finomial, an early stage SaaS company serving the global hedge fund industry from the cloud. Prior to that, he consulted as a hands-on architect to giant corporations (including Microsoft), mid-sized companies, and startups, helping them execute on the cloud by providing architecture guidance, Azure training, and custom development. Bill began working with the Azure cloud platform the day it was unveiled at the Microsoft PDC in 2008 and subsequently founded, in October 2009, Boston Azure, the first Azure-focused community user group in the world. Bill is the author of the book Cloud Architecture Patterns (O’Reilly Media, 2012) which explains patterns and concepts core to understanding how to most effectively use public cloud platforms such as those from Microsoft, Amazon, and Google. Bill is recognized by Microsoft as a Microsoft Azure MVP, a reflection of his Azure cloud expertise and willingness to share it.
results.name: Comparing Azure SQL Database and SQL Server - Bill Wilder

results.description:
The Importance of Sharing Your Story for Increasing Your Professional Value and Rewards


Bonus: First meeting of Test Automation SIG 6-6:30pm 

Speaker:  James Denman

Meeting Date:  Wednesday April[masked]

Meeting Time:  Networking: 6-6:30pm 

Test Automation SIG 6-6:30pm          

Discussion: 6:30-8pm

Location:    Oracle Campus           

45 Network Drive Northwest Park                   

Burlington MA 01803

Cost:          Free! 

Abstract:   

If we do not remember our history, we are doomed to repeat it. Don't reinvent the wheel. There are few problems in life that a little patience and a lot of research can't cure.  These are all good reasons to listen to other people's stories. And if you look a little deeper, they're also good reasons to make sure other people have the chance to listen to yours. At this talk, you will learn:

1. Altruistic reasons to share your knowledge and personal experience

2. Selfish reasons to share your knowledge and personal experience

3. Viable methods for you to share your knowledge and personal experience

4. Advice for getting started sharing your knowledge and experience

Speaker Biography: 

James Denman was a tech journalist for five years. During that time he worked on expert editorial content for application development websitesincluding SearchSOA.com, TheServerSide.com, and SearchSoftwareQuality.com. In June of 2015, James committed to changing career tracks from journalism to application development. Shifting from writing about code to writing code is an amazing transition. It is challenging and rewarding in equal measure. Now James takes a leadership role among three developers working for a very young startup called Qubed Spaces. Until such time as Qubed Spaces starts making money, James works and learns around a regular 40 hour week doing data clean-up on a contract basis at LogMeIn.

Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford Presents EDH Night

results.description:
We're not dead!

Speakers:

Ashley Streb - Rocket Insights recently had the privledge of building a Watch app for Virgin Pulse -- with significant input from Apple designers. We wanted to boil our 3 months of toiling, wringing of hands, sweating the details and hard work into a 20 minute presentation. Here is what we would like to share:

* How to think about and prioritize the capabilities of the watch (glances, app, complication)

* Key decisions on layout of application (hierarchial vs. page, how to handle user logged in / out states)

* Communication patterns for communicating between phone <--> watch

* Layering & Animation

Ron Mourant - Using Open Source Swift in Linux Mint

Rags Srinivas - The case for Swift on the Server

Objective-C led to the unraveling of the App Economy. The Swift language is the successor to Objective-C, which was recently open sourced by Apple. It has had huge levels of interest, both by the open source community and developers, which has led it to being one of the most rapidly growing programming languages. Since the introduction of open source Swift, IBM has been enabling the language on Linux by implementing the APIs and on the IBM Cloud by enabling the community buildpacks on Bluemix, being able to write triggers with Swift on the server side and so on.

During this session, we will present a preview of our latest cloud deployment configurations, Swift package-based cloud services, and tools integration. There is an IBM-provided Swift Sandbox for a sample of Swift running on the cloud.

Come join this session for a “Hello World” with Swift on server and for plans about what is next for Swift @ IBM.
results.name: April Meeting

results.description:
We're back! New location, new time, new content! We'll bring it back with the original 0-day, the buffer overflow. This is a hands-on-keyboard workshop for beginners. We will show you step by step how to create a buffer overflow, and have you follow along.

Location:

Pivotal Labs, 145 Broadway, Cambridge, MA 02142


Across the street from Akamai, near Kendall Sq. in the Cambridge MIT Area. This event will also be Live Streamed to Youtube.

Schedule:

6:30 PM to 7:00 PM - FREE pizza, beer, wine, news

7:00 PM to 8:30 PM - Workshop

8:30 PM - Drinks at Cambridge Brewing Company (not free)

Please arrive before 7:00 PM, you'll need to follow every step from the beginning for the exploit to work.

Audience:

- beginners, students, IT professionals, security enthusiasts

Required: 

- laptop

- any OS (Windows, Mac, Linux)

- Virtualbox, Guest Additions

https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads


- Kali Linux 32-bit PAE VM,[masked]

https://www.offensive-security.com/kali-linux-vmware-virtualbox-image-download/


You must use Virtualbox and Kali Linux 32-bit[masked], the versions are very important.



Buffer Overflow Explained:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1S0aBV-Waeo

The workshop will show you how to compile a simple C program using GCC, configure your virtual environment, debug with GDB, attack it using a Python script, analyze the results, develop a payload, and craft an effective exploit using a NOP sled. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_overflow#NOP_sled_technique

This is a beginners to intermediate focused presentation. No previous security and programming experience is required, just a laptop, Virtualbox, Kali Linux VM, and a willingness to learn. :)

Here is the workshop tutorial:

https://gist.github.com/apolloclark/6cffb33f179cc9162d0a
results.name: Buffer Overflows, the Original 0-Day

results.description:
RSVP now for Wed, Apr 13 -

We have several great speeches lined up for next session, including special guest Michelle Jeffalone.

Michelle works to incorporate presence and warmth in our interactions with others. What does that actually look like in everyday life?
It allows us to be heard, have a voice and listen better
Develop skills to deal with challenging people
And better manage difficult conversations

Her appearance at our Meetup will not make you an expert in all these areas, but you will learn about using mindfulness in your speaking and presentation skills, and gain insight into bringing mindful strategies to other parts of your work and personal life.  I like her philosophy, which aligns with our meetups: "If it isn't fun, it's not sustainable."

In addition, Learn valuable do's and don'ts for addressing an audience. Listen to first-time speakers. And discover how to get over that "anxiety hurdle."

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time (and returning) guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Wed, April 13, (6:45 PM)

Wed, April 27 (6:45 PM)


[No Saturday session for April. Sorry.]


                        ..............................

3rd Floor, Room 097.

You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking (Beware - Metered until 8 PM !), There is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.

results.description:
Joel Fishbein will be leading this sound awareness meditation.  Our event start time is 6:45pm.  But please arrive early to settle in.  

Our schedule:  
6:30pm -  It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat.  We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store. 
6:45pm - Class starts.  
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm.  At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking.  
8:00pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) an experience of a sound awareness meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 

More info: 


Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.  http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/

What to bring: 
It's fine to just show up as you are.  
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor.  Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything. 
If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Sound Awareness Meditation

results.description:
What are some of the basic needs of introverts and extroverts? What are some of the strengths of each type? How do our introverted or extroverted tendencies affect our actions, relationships, and perceptions of others?

Karen will facilitate this month's session where we will explore and discuss the many aspects of introversion and extroversion together. We'll share our own perspectives and some of our personal experiences with one another. As a group of introverts and extroverts, let's learn from each other with the goal of gaining a better understanding of those who approach life differently than we do. 

___________________________________________________

The intention of this salon is to build a community of people interested in personal growth and in sharing that with others. 


The meetings will be facilitated by a different member of the community each month. The first part of each meeting will be a time for people to share the difference personal growth made in their lives over the past month. The experiences shared may be from a new course/offering the person participated in or the result of any growth and development experience they had in the past. They may also share where in their lives  they feel that they need personal growth so that the community, and their participation in the Heart Beat Salon, may support them.

The second part of the evening will be a discussion of a personal growth topic as selected by the facilitator. The facilitator may or may not have in depth knowledge of the topic. Our intention is to hear from a members of the community and to not have this section be led by a professional. 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

The Challenges of Being an Introvert in an Extroverted World

To Prepare ....

1)  What have been your personal growth experiences?   
2) What area of personal growth are you currently at work on? 
3) Is there personal growth you deem as necessary in your life?

Our Leader This Evening

Karen Putnam

Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon?  
  *  Where are Heartbeat Salons  
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Hosts: 
  * How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics to Offer at a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Presenters: 
  * How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Your Suggestions: 
  * Give Us Your Ideas (topics, locations, etc) .

results.description:
The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall. No pressure at all. Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours. Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here:

https://hangouts.google.com/hangouts/_/daviddrayton.com/weeklyautomatedincomemastermindmeeting

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week. This part usually takes about 15 minutes. The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!" Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join. It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in. Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Anodyne and analgesic herbs provide direct relief from pain, but each one has its specific talents and applications. Learning to distinguish the many types and causes of pain, and matching herbs to them, is a subject for long study and practice. There are, however, a few herbs which are very potent and immediate in their effects, and which therefore are better suited to first aid applications.

Ghost Pipe tincture is immensely useful for pain that is overwhelming one’s capacity to function; it helps put the pain at a distance so it feels less intense.

Learn which herbs deserve a place in your first aid kit for when quick relief is needed, how to prepare and utilize them in various situations, and how to combine them to further maximize their efficacy.

results.description:
What would it mean for Austrian Economics to "win"? The reading this week will be a series of recent news articles and Federal Reserve statements that, albeit without explicit reference to the Austrian School, seem to be endorsing parts of the Austrian Theory of the Business Cycle. NOTE: There will be no meeting on Wednesday, April 6.

As Commercial Real-Estate Prices Soar, Fed Weighs Consequences
Wall Street Journal, December 11, 2015

Home Price Rebound Creeps Into Policy Debate of Bubble-Wary Fed
Bloomberg, October 2, 2015

Fed's Asset-Bubble Focus Tries to Clear Path for Gradual Hikes
Bloomberg, December 29, 2015

STUDY QUESTIONS

1.) What is the Austrian Theory of the Business Cycle?

2.) What do Fed officials see as the basic tradeoff that exists in their interest rate policy decisions?

3.) Does Austrian Economics have anything to say about whether this tradeoff should be taken?

4.) What is the Fed's understanding of its ability to fight bubbles by raising interest rates? Are they correct?

5.) If the Fed produces bubbles with low interest rates, and cannot use high interest rates to fight them, what does this say about the Fed?
results.name: HAS AUSTRIAN ECONOMICS WON?

results.description:
The first part of this talk will cover general issues such as the effect of different workloads, measurement pitfalls, and common cheats used by storage vendors. The second part will introduce common tools such as fio and IOzone to measure storage performance.


In the third part, Jeff will demonstrate how to set up and test a popular distributed file systems using these tools, and how to analyze results. Most importantly, attendees will learn to recognize anomalies in their own tests, or misleading results from others', so that they can get an accurate picture of each system's capabilities and
limitations.

Bio:

Jeff Darcy has been working on distributed storage since 1989, when that meant DECnet and NFSv2. Since then he has played a significant role in the development of clustered file systems, continuous data protection, and other areas. He is currently a developer at Red Hat, with the rare opportunity to work on two open-source distributed file systems - GlusterFS and Ceph - at once.
results.name: Jeff Darcy: Evaluating Distributed File System Performance

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom Weekly Dance

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

The program starts promptly at 7:30pm during the fall and winter months,and 8:30pm during the spring and summer months.

Please arrive early as there is no admittance once the program begins.

We start admitting ticketed guests 10 minutes before the program begins.

Right before the program starts and after all the ticketed guests that are present are admitted, we will admit any non-ticketed guests until we reach capacity.

Weather
The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here. Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory): no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time.

Location
The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Avenue in Boston, MA, above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell up to the Observatory is on the fifth floor just to the left of room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.

Information
For information about Open Night, please call[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory):

Source(s):
New member, Manny reminded me about...
http://www.bostonastronomy.net/Public%20Viewing.html
http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/

Watch for tickets here:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-university-open-night-tickets-20559405736
results.name: Boston University - Public Open Night at the Coit Observatory

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:

Organizer/Event Host: 
Jenna (*SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor: 
Wendel C.

Sponsored by: 
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location: 
Abington

Cost: 
$15.00 with Kangoo Jumps rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.

Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP: 
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.

Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- What happens in Kangoo club stays in Kangoo club - pls don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

.- There is no secure place to put your things, open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

 - Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite - Bring a healthy snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

* Future Kangoo Jump Events: 
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 


Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Register at: http://bit.ly/160414Mtup

We have heard about how developers use sprints as an agile tool to get the code shipped. How about using a similar concept for innovating on an idea? Ideas are abundant and many times teams struggle to figure out which ideas to pursue. Design Sprints use a design-thinking-like process to understand which ideas are worth moving to the next steps. 

A design sprint is a 5-step process for solving business problems through design, prototyping, and testing with users. In this interactive workshop you'll learn: 
How to research an idea's merit from a customer's perspective 
How to gain insights from that data (and how different the data may be from what you might expect) 
Modifying, evolving or killing an idea based on that research, prototyping and feedback 
How to define the problem and discover insights focusing on the problem that needs to be addressed, what is currently known, and what more information is necessary 
You’ll have an opportunity to have hands on experience with these activities and tools:
Question formulation 
Discovery interview 
Empathy Map 
Journey Maps 
Challenge Maps 
Scenarios & Storyboarding 
Assumption Table 
Dot-voting 
Make a prototype that can test the core assumptions of the Design Sprint Activities
IMPORTANT: There is a fee for this event.  Please register in advance on the following page: http://bit.ly/160414Mtup

$195 for BPMA Premium members
$295 for BPMA Basic and non-members

Email [masked] for a 10% discount on groups of 3 or more from the same organization who register together. Sign up today for a Premium Membership at $75 and register for this and future workshops at the Premium member rate. Premium Membership allows for free admission to standard monthly events for the next year and access to other special offers.

Fees include a copy of the workshop materials and a mid-afternoon snack. 


Restrictions:

To keep the workshop as interactive as possible, attendance is limited to 25 attendees and will not run with fewer than 7. 

About the Speaker

Richard Banfield, Co-founder and CEO , Fresh Tilled Soil

Richard is a the CEO and co-founder of Fresh Tilled Soil. After completing a degree in Biology, Richard was attracted to the world of web technologies and worked his way up the digital food chain, starting with online ad sales at MultiChoice, Africa’s largest TV and Internet media business. He was in the thick of it during the dot-com years, co-founding Acceleration, an international advertising technology business headquartered in London (now owned by advertising giant WPP).

Under Richard’s leadership Fresh Tilled Soil has delivered digital product design, business strategy, and workshops to 650+ clients across the world. His colorful life experience includes being an officer in the army and being a dive master on the remote Islamic Republic of the Comoros, where he learned the survival skills he uses daily in the fast paced tech world. Richard is a mentor at several incubators and accelerators as well as Advisor and lecturer at the Startup Institute.

Richard recently published two books. Design Leadership is his second book published by O’Reilly. The first was Design Sprint: A Practical Guidebook for Building Great Digital Products, which he coauthored with CTodd Lombardo and Trace Wax.

Linkedin | Twitter | Web


EVENT SPONSOR

Special thanks to event sponsor District Hall.
