results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
We are 1.2 million neighbors, friends, and community leaders who come together to create positive, lasting change in our communities and around the world.

My passion is to take our world class city of Cambridge, MA and make it the leader in community service.  And I need your help.  :)  We meet for lunch every Thursday in Harvard Square. 

Our differing occupations, cultures, and countries give us a unique perspective. Our shared passion for service helps us accomplish the remarkable.

WHAT MAKES US DIFFERENT?
Our distinct point of view and approach gives us unique advantages:

We see differently: Our multidisciplinary perspective helps us see challenges in unique ways.

We think differently: We apply leadership and expertise to social issues—and find unique solutions.

We act responsibly: Our passion and perseverance create lasting change.

We make a difference at home and around the world: Our members can be found in your community and across the globe.

HOW DO WE WORK?
Our impact starts with our members—people who work tirelessly with their clubs to solve some of our communities' toughest challenges. Their efforts are supported by Rotary International, our member association, and The Rotary Foundation, which turns generous donations into grants that fund the work of our members and partners around the world. Rotary is led by our members—responsible leaders who help to carry forward our organization's mission and values in their elected roles. I hope you join us and the world will live as one.  Please email me, [masked]  if you like what you here and want to become part of the solution.

results.description:
Announcing this month's presentations:

Talk #1: Clustering Big Data (featuring OpenLSH)


Talk #2: Anomaly Detection in Spark - interactive discussion and demo.

The envisioned format will be:

6:00 - 6:30 - Networking, food & beverage

6:30 - 6:40 - Message from our sponsors

6:40 - 8:15 - Two talks of 45 minutes long including Q&A

8:15 - 8:30 - Wrap-up


Presentation #1:

Title: Clustering Big Data.

Description: Approximate Nearest Neighbor methods for clustering and indexing have been actively researched ever since the K-Means algorithm was published in 1975 (and coded in FORTRAN). A recent book (https://www.crcpress.com/product/isbn/9781466558212) lists about 300 variants and related topics. 

The talk will feature OpenLSH, a python-based open source implementation of LSH we have been working on. We'll demo the algorithm by analyzing tweets in near-real-time, hopefully we'll find some similar or identical pairs. We're looking for other large data sets to work with and if you know a juicy one, we'd love to hear about it.

Speaker Bios: Dr. J Singh is a Principal at DataThinks.org, a Cloud and Big Data consulting company. He is a frequent speaker on NoSQL, Hadoop--Map/Reduce and analytics of social media. Dr. Singh is an Adjunct Professor of Computer Science at WPI where he covers Database Technology, Big Data and Data Mining. He received his MS-EE (Pattern Recognition) and PhD-EE (Numerical Algorithms) from Syracuse University. 

Teresa Nicole Brooks is a software engineer with a passion for all things data. She has both professional and academic experience in natural language processing, information retrieval, big data processing and search. Her interest in web-scale data mining and search drives her interest in near duplicate document detection and locality sensitive hashing. Some of her technical interests are network and software security, artificial intelligence, knowledge extraction, and recommendation systems. Teresa currently works as a freelance software developer in NYC. She lives with her cat Molly and dog Rondo.

Presentation #2:

Title: Anomaly Detection in Spark

Description: Detection of outliers and anomalies has numerous applications in network security, predictive maintenance, fraud, etc.  Unlike many analytics applications, anomaly detection typically requires utilization of all data without sampling, making it an ideal match for big data tools like Spark.  The most commonly cited approach on big data is the use of clustering; however, clustering and other unsupervised approaches have significant drawbacks.

In this interactive session, we'll discuss the tradeoff between supervised and unsupervised approaches, then show an approach for using supervised models in situations where labeled data does not exist.  Throughout, we'll demonstrate insights over Spark using iPython and an example dataset.

Speaker Bio: Dan Mallinger, Director of Data Science & Strategy at Think Big

results.description:
Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling. 

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you don't mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice. So come join us!  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked]. 

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

Check out our website or find us on Facebook!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet on the boardwalk beneath the Moakley Bridge.  You'll find our tall Team Captain Dave and a group of fun paddlers with Living Root shirts

Come join me in exploring the Boston Children's Museum with no Kids come be a kid again with a cash bar!! tickets are $25 and have to be purchased in advance it will sell out!! buy tickets here
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-grown-ups-museum-tickets-22417315795

Ballgames, brats and brews…Boston Grown-Ups Museum is back so spread the news!! Get ready to kick off spring with a night dedicated to one of Boston’s favorite games!! Show off your expert corn hole skills, throw your best fast ball in our Speed Pitch, and make it to the last block with our giant Jenga set.
Ever wanted to visit Boston Children's Museum...without the children? Race to the the top of the three-story Climb, build a towering fortress, blow a giant bubble, and remember what it's like to be a kid? Now is your chance!
On Thursday, April 14th, we're throwing open the doors to Boston Children's Museum to those who are young at heart. Enjoy beer and wine plus tasty treats for purchase. Bring friends and meet new ones as you explore interactive exhibits, attempt to build a "big kid" sized fort, and explore your inner artist in the Art Studio.
Whether you were here as a kid or are new to town, Boston "Grown-Ups" Museum will bring out your innate sense of fun!

Cover $25

Cash Bar

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4
results.how_to_find_us: Park in the unpaved municipal parking lot to the left of 72 Jefferson Street

We're excited to present Boston’s 2nd Annual Timmy Awards in an effort to recognize the best places for technology professionals to work. We asked the Boston tech community to weigh in by nominating companies they believe deserve to win and then voting for the finalists! 

Organizations and individuals will be crowned the winners in each of the categories below on April 14th. The evening will begin with cocktails, hor d'oeuvres, music and product demos from the best of the best in Boston tech. 

Boston's Best Technology Manager  

Andrew Harmon - VP, C4ISR Technology of Novetta
Brian Cardarella - CEO of Dockyard
David Cancel - CEO of Drift
Sean Lindsay - CTO of Tapjoy
Tomas Revesz - CTO of EverQuote

Boston's Best Technology Work Culture (Under 500 Employees) 

Formlabs
Jebbit
Leanbox
Nanigans
Yesware

Boston's Best Technology Work Culture (Over 500 Employees)

Agero
Athenahealth
Carbon Black
Curriculum Associates
Datto

Boston's Best Tech Startup  


Drizly
Freight Farms
HelloShopper
HourlyNerd
Indico
Onshape
PatientPing
Perfecto Mobile
SnapApp
VirZOOM

Demo Companies


MC10 is on a mission to improve human health through digital healthcare solutions. The company combines its proprietary ultra-thin, flexible body-worn sensors with advanced analytics to unlock health insights from physiological data. MC10 partners with healthcare organizations and researchers to advance medical knowledge and create monitoring and diagnostic solutions for patients and physicians. Backed by a strong syndicate of financial and strategic investors, MC10 has received widespread recognition for its innovative technology, including distinction as a 2014 CES Innovation in Design Honoree. 

Panoptes Systems Corporation (“Panoptes”), founded in 2014 as a spin-off from Aurora Flight Sciences, is focused on the singular mission of giving small unmanned aerial systems (sUAS) “all-seeing” awareness of their flight environment, enabling their safe and efficient operation for any application. Through combining ever more capable and smaller sensors, efficient algorithms, vehicle integration expertise, a deep understanding of operating conditions and real user needs, Panoptes creates systems that enable sUAS to accomplish their evolving and increasingly demanding commercial missions. 

Wayfair offers a zillion things home and soon our products can be seen in a new dimension using augmented and virtual reality. The team at Wayfair Next is building the home visualization and customization tools of the future and we will have an exciting virtual reality demo to unveil at the Timmy Awards.

The Timmy Awards Host, Scott Kirsner

Scott Kirsner is a journalist who writes about innovation and entrepreneurship. His “Innovation Economy” column appears Sundays in the Boston Globe, and he also writes a companion blog for BetaBoston. He is also editor of the site Innovation Leader, which focuses on R&D, product development, and new initiatives within large companies. Scott has been a regular contributor to Fast Company, BusinessWeek, Variety, and Wired. Scott’s writing has also appeared in the New York Times, The Hollywood Reporter, Salon, the San Jose Mercury News, and Newsweek, among other publications. He can be reached at [masked] and his Twitter handle is @ScottKirsner.


Learn More About Our Sponsors: 

Education First  is most widely known as the world's leading international education company.  You may be surprised to hear that technology, design and innovation are always at the core of our work in travel, language learning, cultural exchange and education.  From launching what has grown into the world's largest online English school with Apple back in the '90s, to our more recent work with LinkedIn on democratizing credentialing for global language learners, our innovation teams experiment with cutting edge and emerging technologies while driving our mission of opening the world through education.  

Foodler is a Boston based online food ordering service that connects consumers and companies with a wide variety of restaurants for immediate delivery. Delivery via Foodler is available from more than 12,000 restaurants in 48 states across the US. Breakfast, lunch and dinner options are available as well as alcohol, catering, desserts and more. Foodler has a top rated customer service and an industry leading rewards program. 

TriNet is a leading provider of a comprehensive human resources solution for small to medium-sized businesses. Our HR solution includes services such as payroll processing, human capital consulting, employment law compliance and employee benefits, including health insurance, retirement plans and workers compensation insurance. At Trinet, we understand there is a difference between running a business and employing people. Our model allows you to focus more on your business, and lets us help you manage your people.

cove is building neighborhood productive spaces, where people come to our physical locations to get things done. We know all too well about trying to work at the kitchen table, getting lost in a row of cubicles, or fighting to find an outlet in the coffee shop. cove has everything you need to be productive—free coffee, fast wifi, color printers, and conference rooms. Powered by user­-friendly technology, members can track their usage, make reservations, share interests and skills, and connect with cove’s community. So ditch the busy coffee shop, office cubicle, and living room, and join us. cove launched in DC and expanded to Boston in 2015 with locations in the Back Bay, South End and Union Square (Somerville). 

As always we would like to thank our sponsors Workbridge Associates and Jobspring Partners for sponsoring this month’s event. Interested in sponsoring a Tech in Motion event? Click Here!


*We currently have two staffing firms dedicated to offering career counseling services to our members, so we ask that recruiters not join this group. Any outside recruiter will be removed, thank you for understanding!
results.name: 2nd Annual Timmy Awards

results.description:
Thoreau’s Legacy: A Modern Lyceum

Free and open to the public. Event link HERE. 

Thursday, April 14th, 6:30-8pm (doors @ 6pm)


Old South Meeting House - 310 Washington St, Boston 

:: :: ::

During this event, panelists and audience members will explore today’s educational challenges through the vantage point of Henry David Thoreau and his fellow Transcendentalists, including Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, Margaret Fuller, and Bronson Alcott, all advocates of non-traditional education. Panelists include Megan Marshall, Lawrence Buell, Ph.D. and Jeffrey S. Cramer.

The panelists and audience will explore today’s colossal educational challenges from the vantage point of Thoreau and his fellow Transcendentalists, including Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, Margaret Fuller, and Bronson Alcott, all advocates of non-traditional education. We will also consider the enormous gaps in access to education in today’s society and bring Thoreau’s views on social, individual, and governmental responsibility to bear on possible solutions in that regard.

:: :: ::

Panelists:

Megan Marshall, Charles Wesley Emerson College Professor, Emerson College, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Margaret Fuller: A New American Life and The Peabody Sisters: Three Women Who Ignited American Romanticism

Lawrence Buell, Ph.D., Professor of American Literature Emeritus at Harvard University and former Harvard College Dean of Undergraduate Education

This event is part of the Old South Meeting House Partners in Public Dialogue program. It is presented by The Walden Woods Project.
results.name: Thoreau’s Legacy

results.description:
The Boston area has the most diverse information security ecosystem in the world.  Over the past several years our local community has been increasingly underserved and misaligned, so we are trying to do our part by launching a new monthly meetup (and more).  We understand that the current community has several various meetups/events and expect some skepticism, so let us tell you what we are about:

• We are putting this together for practitioners to have a safe place to come meet likeminded people, share cool ideas, and discuss real issues.

• This event is not a place for marketing, selling product, or recruiting.  We will politely ask anyone that engages in this activity to leave (this includes sponsors).

• Content will be driven by the community.  We also remember that a big part of these events is to bring the community together, so lightining talks are preferred.  This will not be a place that you come after work to watch people lecture at you for three hours.

• RSVP's are highly encouraged, but all practitioners, or those interested in learning about security, are encouraged to come eat, drink, meet others in the community, and share ideas... no strings attached.

For our first meetup, we'll have a handful of practitioners giving 10-15 minute lightning talks (with Q&A) about things they've been working on. Our talks include:

Jen Andre


The multi-headed hydra: scaling your security team without security personnel

It is a universal truth that security teams have too much to do and never enough resources to do it.  

Traditionally, there are tactical tasks that security organizations own that we all hate doing: event triage, managing vulnerabilities, and more.  These tasks lead to alert fatigue and more: they suck up value time that security experts could be using to strategically design and improve security defenses.

WHAT IF:

You could scale your security tasks beyond your organization?

Instead of wagging fingers and waving sticks, you could instill a sense of ownership of security posture across your engineering and operations organizations?

This isn’t a pipe dream, this is happening: let’s look at how some other modern companies are scaling their security organizations without security personnel.

Will Lefevers

Malware Bestiary: "File-less Malware" on Windows

Most security solutions today rely on signatures to catch known-bad executable files on disk in order to prevent malware from running. New breeds of malware like Powerliks and Kovter avoid detection by never writing a file to the disk. How are these malware installed? How do they persist across reboots? How can we find them? Will will provide a quick tour of this new class of malware.

Dustin Webber


High performance network security monitoring leveraging container networking

I'll be talking about high capacity network security monitoring (NSM) leveraging containers for modularity and performance. Learn why using modern container orchestration platforms to easily deploy complex sensor grids is now possible!


Justin Pagano 


Information Security teams are trying to manage increasingly complex IT and cloud environments at their organizations while also keeping pace with an ever-changing threat landscape. At the same time, there's a well-documented issue of unfilled security positions around the world.
For many teams this has inevitably led to security control gaps, operational failures, and, overall, insufficient security across virtually all industries.
A critical and necessary part of the solution to this problem for any organization is broad automation of disparate technologies and processes across the entire InfoSec lifecycle (protect > detect > remediate). There are a number of potential benefits of automating to this extent: more maintainable, auditable, maturable, predictable, and effective security programs.
In this presentation and the Q&A, the speakers will cover:
1. InfoSec programs' current state of affairs with fragmented, siloed automation
2. Strategy for approaching broad security automation
3. Specific examples of broad automation at Rapid7 (current and future state)
results.name: Boston Security Meetup - Introduction!

results.description:
Boston Clojure Group Meetups are held at Akamai in the conference rooms on the second floor (200C/D).

Please join us for a night of Clojure related discussion and group activities.

Meet & Greet starts at 6:00. Pizza and drinks are provided! Group activities will begin at approximately 6:30.

Future meeting ideas will be discussed over the meetup board and in our Google discussion group:  https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/boston-clojure .

Agenda for this meeting:


1. I'll give a quick recap/report on the ClojureBridge Boston programming workshop that was held on March 19th.


2. Call for presentations. What interests you? What can you share? People have mentioned in core.async, om-next, testing, plumatic schema, and more.


3. I'll give a (very) basic charting demo, showing how I've been using Clojure's "frequencies" function + Incanter bar charts to produce interesting charts quickly and easily.


4. We'll pick up where we left off on our Charting Dojo.


• We have a data set (environmental data)

• We have a collaborative hacking server for remote pairing with tmux

• We have a preliminary choices for UI and charting (reagent, highcharts) - though these choices are open to reconsideration.


Let's take the next step to generate some charts from the data set!

All:  This can be as much about a freewheeling discussion of Clojure's libraries, tools, and strengths at data manipulation as it is about hacking something together.  There's no pressure to take the keyboard if you just want to watch.

This is your meetup everyone. Please help shape its direction by sharing ideas and opinions on what we should do with it.  Thanks!

results.description:
At its core, User Experience (UX) is defined as how people respond to using a product, system, or service. Regardless of what we’re designing—a website, an Android app, or a toaster—we all strive to make our designs useful, easy to use, and enjoyable to use. But how exactly do we make something useful, easy to use, and enjoyable? How do we know if the target audience is having a good or bad experience? This class will arm you with the essential tips to find those answers. 

Who should take this class?

This class is for anyone who makes (or wants to learn how to make) clean, usable websites, mobile apps, or other software. Anyone—developers, designers, project managers, content creators, or anyone else—can integrate these UX concepts and best practices into their process.

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct. 


Takeaways

We’ll cover the fundamental concepts of great user experience design and research, including:


• What UX design is and why it's important


• Usability testing


• Users and user personas


• Delivering great user experiences: Best practices, tools of the trade, & professional recommendations


Class Schedule

The class will take place on Thursday, April 14th from 6:30-8:30pm.

Instructor

Jamie Lee Connor

Jamie works as a User Experience Designer on the Product Management team at Epsilon, a global leader in data-driven marketing. She spends her time creating, testing and iterating on prototypes with the goal of building intuitive and easy to use products.

Previously, she worked as a Front-end Developer designing and building websites and as a Visual Designer on a global marketing team. Jamie studied Graphic Design at Massachusetts College of Art & Design and has been continuously learning ever since. She is excited to help women transition into the tech field and expand their skill set!

LinkedIn | Twitter

Pre-reqs & Preparation

No prior experience is necessary. 

Be sure to bring:

• A notebook and writing utensil

• A photo ID, for security reasons

• (optional) A laptop, if you'd like to follow along with the slides as we go

Location


A huge thank you to Velir for hosting this event! 


Velir is located at:


212 Elm St.
Somerville, MA 02144

Teaching Assistants

If you are interested in being a teaching assistant, please fill out our volunteer form. TAing is a great way to practice what you know and to get to know members of our community.

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!
results.name: User Experience & Usability Concepts

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].

If it's your first time at one of my games RSVP on meetup then text, email, or call to confirm your RSVP and receive the address. If you RSVP and no-show without changing your RSVP, then you have likely taken a seat from someone else, made me very sad, and I put your name on the shit list. Don't do it. -1 chip=call

-Verbally declared actions are binding

-No string bets or splashed pots

Over the years that Photography workshops has been in existence many of you have asked me to demonstrate my post-processing techniques for portraits. 

I have generally resisted, not because I want to be difficult but because a certain amount of how I post-process is rather intuitive and can't easily be broken down into individual easy to understand teachable steps. 

Additionally, much of it involves the use of multiple and complex sets of blended Photoshop Layers and the occasional use of plugins such as Nik and several regularly used Photoshop actions.

That said, after several years of pondering how to teach a class on this, I believe I have managed to come up with an approach that will work. 

Join me in this three hour introduction in which I will walk you through how to post-process your portraits to produce high quality results. 

 The techniques  taught will be based on easily adapted features of Lightroom and Photoshop. 

It's a trial run so I am keeping the cost low. ($20) 

You are welcome to bring along a lap-top to follow-along.

results.description:
We will take a look at the FREE tools that you can use to maintain your privacy online, and discuss which ones are best for your needs.

Security and privacy - what does it mean to you in your everyday life? It used to be hard to use the tools that safeguard your identity and your information online. You had to be a pretty technical person - the good news is that it has gotten easier to be secure in your online persona.

These are some of the tools we will look at:

1. Off-the-Record (OTR) Messaging allows you to have private conversations over instant messaging.
2. Email Encryption using Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is a data encryption and decryption computer program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication. There is also the GnuPG system here: https://emailselfdefense.fsf.org/en
3. Tails is a live operating system, that you can start on almost any computer from a DVD, USB stick, or SD card. It aims at preserving your privacy and anonymity.

There are also some great apps for secure texting and secure phones that provide end-to-end encryption for your calls, securing your conversations so that nobody can listen in. There is no way to be bulletproof, but knowing about the options available can provide a measure of security. It is ultimately up to you to decide how much security you want.

Link to hangout: https://plus.google.com/hangouts/_/event/cjfhrydio4rhi9bpgih1coop154?hl=en
results.how_to_find_us: https://plus.google.com/hangouts/_/event/cjfhrydio4rhi9bpgih1coop154?hl=en
results.name: Virtual Meetup: Staying Safe - Overview of FREE Encryption Tools

results.description:
One exercise that sounds interesting goes as follows:

One person plays until they settle on a groove. That person looks to the left and nods. While the first person continues repeating, the second person (to the left) finds a complementary groove. Once everyone is playing, the first person finds a new part to play, and so on.

We could try that for a bit. Also, if anyone has a white board... feel free to bring it.

results.description:
There is a growing demand to source a wide range of chemical products (for example, plant-derived extracts) from engineered microbes. While recent advances in synthetic biology and metabolic engineering make this work technically feasible, commercial success is hindered by the cost to develop the microbes. Development has been costly because the complexity and diversity of biology favored a labor-intensive, small-batch approach to engineering. Ginkgo has built a foundry that allows many microbial engineering projects to use shared processes in a high-throughput, largely-automated fashion, that unlocks substantial economies of scale. In this talk, I will outline the approach, custom software, and hardware that we use to allow flexibility and scale to co-exist where previously one came at the expense of the other. I will illustrate this with examples from each stage of the engineering process across representative projects.

Barry Canton co-founded synthetic biology company Ginkgo Bioworks in 2008 and has helped build the company to 55 people and raised more than $50M in investment over the last year. At Ginkgo, Barry is responsible for the development of the foundry, a centralized facility for organism engineering. In this role he oversees the development of hardware, software, and wetware technologies. Earlier, he led the development of new methods for assembling DNA from standard parts. He holds a PhD in Biological Engineering from MIT, where his thesis focused on refinement of standard biological parts and the interactions between a host cell and an engineered genetic circuit. At MIT, he was involved with the Synthetic Biology Working Group that was instrumental in catalyzing the new field. He also holds an MEngSc in Mechanical Engineering from University College Dublin.

This joint meeting of the GBC/ACM and the Boston Chapter of the IEEE Computer Society will be held in the main auditorium on the 1st floor of the Broad Institute, corner of Main and Vassar Streets in Cambridge.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in the main auditorium on the 1st floor of the Broad Institute, corner of Main and Vassar Streets in Cambridge.
results.name: Balancing flexibility and scale in a synthetic biology foundry with Barry Canton

results.description:
We will explore how to love people for who they are, how to look past their behaviors, past our expectations, and come to appreciate the other person for the gifts they uniquely bring to us.

This evening is for anyone who is in a relationship, whether with a spouse, partner, a child, a family member, friend or a work colleague... everyone!

The core challenge for people in relationship is to  accept the other person as they are and for who they are.  We get caught up in who we want people to be, or who we think they should be. It gets really messy. To create healthy relationships, it is essential to learn to stop demanding that others become whom we want them to be. 

By looking through the "eyes of our heart" we are better able to see and connect with the authentic being we are with. How we communicate, manage our expectations  and how we work through our own disappointment and frustration, will have a major impact on how well the relationship will work. 

We also can take responsibility for lovingly helping others understand and appreciate who we truly are, and help them navigate the distance between their fantasized expectation of ourselves and the sweet reality that is us.

This mini-Workshop is open to all.  For Insight Grads, the price is $20 (and you may bring one non-Grad guest for free.)  For non-Grads, the price is $10.

We truly hope you can join us for what we know will be a great night.

Janet Parker has devoted over 20 years, as a facilitator of personal growth seminars, as a facilitator of business training programs, and as a personal coach, to help people in all walks of life create happier and more fulfilling lives.  


Ms. Parker has been a facilitator with Insight Seminars for over 25 years. Janet contracts as a coach, training designer and trainer with organizations in the Boston area, and has developed and led programs on leadership, communications, team building and more. She currently works with Keystone Associates.

Please also consider joining us for our next Insight I "Awakening Heart Seminar" April 29th - May 1st.

You can also join us April 7th with Insight Facilitator Peter Felsmann who will be leading a webinar on "The Secrets of Having Good Luck."

{Find more Insight events on the Insight Boston website.}
results.name: Insight: Relationships: Seeing through the Eyes of Your Heart

Please register for IOT Big Data Ingestion and Processing in Hadoop/Apex by Silver Springs Network: 

https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/8053824090531525379

Topics include 

- SilverLink Data Platform Overview 

- Ingesting real time data streams from connected sensors into Hadoop using Apex

- Throughput management in Apache Apex applications 

- Processing batch data 

- Hackathon 

Presenter 1: Raja Ali - A Silicon Valley veteran who has spent his career in building, operating and tuning data-centric applications. At Silver Spring Networks, he is the multi-talented architect, evangelist and hands-on developer of the Silverlink Data Platform. Raja is an Apache Apex committer Raja is an avid runner and has run many ultra-marathons. 

Presenter 2: Greg Brosman - Is the Product Manager for the SilverLink Data Platform, where he drives its adoption across Silver Spring’s utility and software partners. Previously he worked on rolling out Silver Spring’s first Network-as-a-Service solution in Copenhagen and a variety of Smart City projects. Greg is a passionate board game player. 

Presenter 3: Darin Nee - Apache Apex committer. A big data software engineer with Silver Spring Network, working on SilverLink Data Platform. 

-------------------------------------------------------------- 

Silver Spring Networks is the world’s largest IOT company with more than 23 million endpoints deployed. We help global utilities and cities connect, optimize, and manage smart energy and smart city infrastructure. 

Our big data platform utilizes technology from the Apache Hadoop ecosystem to collect, process and analyze large volumes of streaming data. Apache Apex is a central part of our technology stack. We rely on it to scale our processing pipelines to manage billions of data points every day in a scalable, reliable manner. 

-------------------------------------------------------------

April showers got you down? Get it up with Boston's best night of sketch and comedy!

TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sketchhaus-tickets-19934055296

YOUR HEADLINER: Boston's best and funniest panel show, INTERESTING POINTS. What is it about funny people that makes them interesting? Is it the things they know or the things they do? Is it the memories they share or the lies they make up? Whatever it is, it's hilarious. Join standup comedians Kathe Farris, Jessie Farris, and Andrew George and sketch performers Lauren Walleser (Mister Bismuth) and Allen McRae (Terrible People) and host Kevin Quigley (sketch god) as they tackle "The Elephant In the Room."

PLUS: AND NOW YOU KNOW. Did you know that cheese triggers the same part of the brain as hard drugs? Come watch as Diane's friends stage a cheddar-vention. Did you know that chlamydia's fastest growing population is the elderly? Learn how to have this challenging conversation with your grandparents. Inspired by viral social media threads like IFLScience and Buzzfeed, this sketch show will present fascinating (if not slightly disturbing) facts in the form of wacky public service announcements and scenes. Featuring an all-star cast from some of Boston's leading sketch teams (One Joke Pony, Accidental Awkwardness, Part of Your World) you'll laugh and learn at the same time!

With your host Andrew George and Special Guest Stars Kathe & Jessie Farris, this Thursday is the best way to kick off your weekend! ALSO: only $12 (cheap!)

results.description:
April 16, 2016

Why Being a Better Listener Makes You More Successful</a>

Amy Falk, Syndala Life Coaching

Featured speaker Amy Falk of Syndala Life Coaching will explain why improving your listening skills will increase your company’s bottom line, make you a better leader, and enhance your relationships, in and out of work.

Listening is key to the communication process and one of the most important skills we can master. How well we listen has a major impact on our work effectiveness, but the benefits extend far beyond professional and academic settings. Being a good listener fosters better-quality relationships with others, improved self-esteem and even better health and well-being. However, most people are not very good listeners and they are paying a price in their professional and personal lives. Fortunately, listening is a skill we can learn, improve, and continue to practice. Amy Falk will focus on the different types of listening, the most common barriers to effective listening, and how we can become better listeners

About the Speaker: Amy Falk of Syndala Life Coaching is a Certified Life Coach who loves working with smart, creative types who have many interests, passions and ideas, but often struggle to start and/or complete them. She has special training to work with adults, college students and teens with ADD/ADHD. Amy received her B.A. from Franklin & Marshall College, completed her formal coach training and certification with the Coaches Training Institute, and completed specialized ADHD Coach Training with JST Coaching. She studied for several years with Rick Carson, author of Taming Your Gremlin, which she found to be a life-changing book and paradigm. Amy is a founding board member and performer with Voices of Hope, an all-volunteer, non-profit organization that uses musical performance to raise funds and awareness for cancer research. Amy is also an artist; see some of her work at Syndala Designs on Etsy and Facebook. She lives in Reading, MA, with her husband, daughter, and two dogs. For more information, contact Amy at <a href="mailto:[masked]">[masked] or visit www.syndala.com.

This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. We'll wait about 15 minutes before starting the walk.  Running really late? You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk.  

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
I would like to invite you to a two-part series on Papermaking. Session 1 on Friday April 15 at 1:30 pm is making paper at the Museum School, which is across the street from the Museum. Session 2 is on Friday May 13 at 1:30 pm and is at the Museum. Session 2 focuses on the differences between eastern and western papers, history, and conservation.
If you have never made paper before, it’s fun! It is also fascinating. And if you have never explored the various types of handmade paper that artists and writers work with, and how they are made, well, that is fascinating too! Please RSVP for Session 1 by April 7, and Session 2 by May 6. Space is limited for Session 1. To RSVP for any of these programs,, I welcome your phone call! I can be reached at[masked]-3189. Please let me know if you have any questions. I hope to see you soon! Hannah Goodwin
Manager of Accessibility
Museum of Fine Arts, Boston

results.description:
Havurah on the Hill Young Adult Monthly Kabbalat Shabbat featuring Jonathan Soroff of the Improper Bostonian. Save the date for our April Kabbalat Shabbat featuring Jonathan Soroff of the Improper Bostonian. Jonathan Soroff was born and raised in Newton, where he still lives with his better half, Sam Mazzarelli. After graduating from Duke University in 1987, Soroff went to work for the Boston Herald and eventually became the nightlife/lifestyle trends columnist. For the past 24 years, he has been the lead columnist for the Improper Bostonian Magazine, where he writes the social column and a celebrity interview in every issue and contributes features throughout the year. He is the author of the novel "Crimes of Fashion,” has written for everyone from People to Instinct to the Royal Academy Magazine (London), and does extensive travel writing for national and international publications. He is the creator of the blog www.itsmylifegetyourown.com and co-hosts a radio show, Status Report, on Boston Herald Radio. He serves on the board of directors of the NET Research Foundation and the advisory board of the Trustees of the Reservations, is an overseer of the Boston Ballet and a corporator of Beaver Country Day School. His favorite color is purple. Schedule of Events:
6:30 PM Wine and Appetizers
7:00 PM Shabbat Services
8:15 PM Discussion with our Featured Speaker
8:45 PM Kosher Buffet Shabbat Dinner
(vegetarian and gluten free options available)

New faces are always welcome at Havurah on the Hill, so bring your friends.

Suggested donation $10.00 per person.
Registration will be open soon!


Free validated parking is always available for Havurah on the Hill's monthly Shabbat celebrations at the Charles River Garage (165 Cambridge Street, Boston). Please note that this is NOT the above-ground Whole Foods lot, but the parking garage bewteen the Whole Foods lot and the Au Bon Pain. Please bring your green ticket into the Vilna for a validation stamp. The Vilna Shul is also easily accessible by public transportation. Take the MBTA Red Line to Charles/MGH. For driving, walking and public transport directions, please visit http://www.vilnashul.org/about/location.

Havurah on the Hill is a non-denominational, egalitarian minyan for Jews in their 20s and 30s in the Boston area. HOH meets at the Vilna Shul in Beacon Hill, one of the last remaining synagogues from the early 20th century wave of Jewish immigration and hosts monthly Kabbalat Shabbat services as well as other special holiday celebrations throughout the year.
results.name: HOH Young Adult Shabbat with Jonathan Soroff of the Improper Bostonian.

results.description:
Join us for a fun, stimulating evening of group critique and discussion.

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion. Please note: In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, in winter, spring, summer, and fall.

Join Psychic Mediums Julie Ann Gadziala from New Hampshire Metaphysical & Genevieve Hackett from Central Mass Serenity for an evening of Laughter and Love. Receive Beautiful Messages, Spirit Connections and Divine Inspirations. Dine on the shore of the Concord River in Billerica. Savor the flavors of homestyle cuisine fresh from the kitchen at Stelio's Family Restaurant (Stelio's Website).


Genevieve and Julie Ann will mingle with you while you eat to begin to bring connections directly to you. They will also connect in the more traditional 'Gallery Style Tradition' while sitting in front of the group. 

Your buffet meal includes a full dinner with chicken, beef, fish or vegetarian options and includes dessert and coffee. Tables seat 8. You can reserve your own table of 8 (email the request) or you will share your table with new friends yet to meet. CASH BAR is available throughout the event. 

EARLY BIRD TICKETS (sold in March) $60. http://steliosevent.eventbrite.com  REGULAR TICKETS (sold in April) $70. http://steliosevent.eventbrite.com

•                        About Julie Ann Gadziala:


Julie Ann Gadziala currently maintains a successful Private Practice as a Psychic Medium, Channeler, Spiritual Business Coach and Mentor as well as overseeing her business “New Hampshire Metaphysical” in Londonderry, NH. You will also find her holding sessions at Circles of Wisdom in Andover MA. For Information and Testimonials about Julie Ann visit her at: JulieAnnGadziala.com or Julie Ann's Website. You can contact Julie Ann directly by emailing: [masked].


                       About Genevieve Hackett:

Genevieve Hackett is a brilliantly talented Psychic Medium, Healer,Teacher and Spiritual Guide. Genevieve has touched the lives of so many people in crisis and brought her beautiful gifts of healing light and spiritual connection to them. She has an astonishing ability to get right to the core of where people are coming from and where they need to be going to. As well as able to bring the correct healing modality into her sessions. You will find her working at numerous locations in MA and NH. For Information and Testimonials about Genevieve visit her at Genevieve's Website. You can contact her directly by emailing: [masked].

Testimonials:

GENEVIEVE

"My reading with you was nothing short of amazing and glorious.  You were able to connect to those who wished to come through with such ease as well as connect directly to those I asked you too.   You were able to make those connections with almost no effort.  It was as if my family on the other side felt as comfortable with you as I did and wanted you to deliver messages to me.  I have not had this happen with others in the past.  You were able to bring information through in such a clear and often times humorous way that our time flew by.  The messages I received will stay with me forever.  I also want you to know that I shared with my husband the messages you brought through from his mother.  He was very happy to hear them.  Thank you Genevieve.  I would love to have you come to a family gathering sometime.  Until then please continue what you are doing… you are gifted and bring such joy to your clients!" RR

"Genevieve's strong connections to Spirit, Higher Self, Channel energies and the Christ Consciousness just exude from her. Genevieve is all about love, laughter, joy and healing. Be ready to have your world "Rocked In A Positive Way" once you begin sessions with her. If you are in need of healing, direction or connection to Spirit, find your way to Genevieve.  I am one of the lucky ones and most blessed to have been able to sit in private session with her. Genevieve is a sheer joy and blessing to all who find their way to her on their path."  JAG

JULIE ANN


"Julie Ann is a warm, wonderful, and Gifted practitioner. Through her mediumship gift I have come to know, absolutely, that loved ones who have crossed over are around me. I had never had a reading w/Julie Ann & she was able to describe in detail these folks & bring messages forth.There is no way she could have known-Amazing! Her channeling gift has help understand why I am " drawn" to certain historic events, and why I have certain interests & passions in present life. I completely trust Julie Ann and have been seeing her for years. Thank you Julie Ann for sharing your gifts." LL


"Julie Ann has a profound psychic ability. I have both experienced her gift personally and I have witnessed her keen ability with others. She is also a great Channeler. She has a deep connection with her spirit world and relates to her clients what they need in their lives from the spirit world perspective which is so in tune with what each of us need to hear. Notwithstanding is her mediumship abilities. She is ALWAYS spot on with her clients family & friends in afterlife. I recommend her highly." DL

</a>

ONE Cantonese Event each Friday evening - with SEVERAL ACCOMPLISHED Cantonese speakers/teachers/guides - at the Huntington Avenue YMCA/Hastings Hall - Room # 101

The ONLY entrance is at 320 Huntington Avenue.

The weekly Cantonese-English chat begins with a one-hour level 1 Cantonese language class followed by a free chat. 

<a href="https://www.google.com/maps/dir/">https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until mid-April, Dandan's YMCA-based Cantonese-English class and chat will be in in Boston YMCA 101.

Dandan 'Danni' Mai and Xiao 'Cecelia' Xiu, from the PRC (and NEU), host these friendly meetups (in Boston YMCA 101), and Frankie Presta may also instruct.

* Cantonese speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?  
* English speakers want to learn Cantonese?  
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Cantonese?

Schedule: 
6:00 - 7:00PM - Cantonese class 
7:00 - 9:00PM - Bilingual free chat.

6:00 - 7:00 - 廣東話班
7:00 - 9:00 - 雙語談話

* Green Line E-Line comes above ground to Northeastern, and the YMCA is around the corner.
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, walking through Northeastern University.
* Walking from Brookline is about 15 minutes.
* MFA, Wentworth, College, and Harvard's LMA are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue. 
* Route 9 comes near the area, via Brookline.
* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find).

New England Conservatory (NEU) is on the corner, followed by The Huntington Avenue YMCA, and then the entrance to Hasting fall is at the end of that block at 320 Huntington Avenue.  This building is OWNED BY NEU.

By MBTA, get off at 

• Northeastern University stop on Huntington Avenue E-Line (MBTA Green E) 
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on the Orange Line (then walk around NEC to YMCA).
• New England Conservatory stop on #39 bus
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on #1 bus from Harvard Square (then walk around NEC to YMCA).

results.description:
Looking Inside a Person’s Mind

Can we see inside a person’s mind by looking at their brain?  Some neuroscientists say we can.

This meeting will concentrate on a single question: Is it possible to extract a picture of what you see from measurements of your visual cortex?

The question gives rise to several problems.  The first problem revolves around the ambiguity of the expression “what you see”.  There are two ways to read that expression:

(a)  “what you see” refers to something external.  For example, “what you see” refers to the cause of your visual experience, namely the scene you are looking at.

(b)  “what you see” refers to something internal.  For example, “what you see” refers to your visual experience itself (the mental image you form).

Consider the question again.  Is it possible to extract a picture of what you see from measurements of your visual cortex?  If “what you see” is used in sense (a), then the answer is “probably yes”.  If “what you see” is used in sense (b), then the answer is “no”.

A second problem has to do with conscious experience.  Is there is a difference between the mental event (your conscious experience of the scene) and the physical event (the brain activity that causes the visual experience)?  We normally assume there is a difference.  Can neuroscience safely ignore this difference?

The reason these questions are important is that some neuroscientists claim that they are able to extract a picture of what a person sees (a mental image) by measuring the brain’s activity.  They believe that by measuring changes of blood flow in the visual cortex with an MRI machine they can reconstruct a picture of what a person sees (the mental image). [References 1, 2 and 3]

The neuroscientist seem to be claiming that they can reach into a person’s mind and capture a picture of the mental image that a person has in their head.  At a minimum, this claim is misleading.

According to some, the neuroscientists should not say, “They reconstruct mental images by measuring the brain’s activity.”  Instead, they should say, “They reconstruct a picture of the external scene (that produced the mental image) by measuring the brain’s activity.”  While the first statement is shorter, it exaggerates what neuroscientists are doing.  They are not reconstructing mental images.  It is misleading to say so.  The second statement provides a more accurate statement of the facts.

Here is a diagrams showing how pictures & mental images are extracted from a person's brain.

http://files.meetup.com/331299/Diagrams%20for%20Extracting%20Pictures%20%26%20Images%20%28April%202016%29.pdf

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~


Donations:

To help support the Democracy Center, a voluntary donation will be requested at the meeting.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~

References:

The references below are for articles that purport to show that (a person’s) visual images can be extracted from MRI measurements (of a person’s) brain activity. The MRI machine measures blood oxygen level dependent (BOLD) signals in the brain.

Reference 1:

“Identifying natural images from human brain activity”

Kendrick N. Kay, Thomas Naselaris, Ryan J. Prenger & Jack L. Gallant 

Nature 452,[masked] (20 March 2008)

Abstract A challenging goal in neuroscience is to be able to read out, or decode, mental content from brain activity. Recent functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies have decoded orientation, position and object category from activity in visual cortex. However, these studies typically used relatively simple stimuli (for example, gratings) or images drawn from fixed categories (for example, faces, houses), and decoding was based on previous measurements of brain activity evoked by those same stimuli or categories. To overcome these limitations, here we develop a decoding method based on quantitative receptive-field models that characterize the relationship between visual stimuli and fMRI activity in early visual areas. These models describe the tuning of individual voxels for space, orientation and spatial frequency, and are estimated directly from responses evoked by natural images. We show that these receptive-field models make it possible to identify, from a large set of completely novel natural images, which specific image was seen by an observer. Identification is not a mere consequence of the retinotopic organization of visual areas; simpler receptive-field models that describe only spatial tuning yield much poorer identification performance. Our results suggest that it may soon be possible to reconstruct a picture of a person's visual experience from measurements of brain activity alone.

Reference 2:

“Inverse retinotopy: Inferring the visual content of images from brain activation patterns”

Bertrand Thirion, et al

NeuroImage, Vol. 33, Issue 4, (2006)

Abstract Traditional inference in neuroimaging consists in describing brain activations elicited and modulated by different kinds of stimuli. Recently, however, paradigms have been studied in which the converse operation is performed, thus inferring behavioral or mental states associated with activation images. Here, we use the well-known retinotopy of the visual cortex to infer the visual content of real or imaginary scenes from the brain activation patterns that they elicit. We present two decoding algorithms: an explicit technique, based on the current knowledge of the retinotopic structure of the visual areas, and an implicit technique, based on supervised classifiers. Both algorithms predicted the stimulus identity with significant accuracy. Furthermore, we extend this principle to mental imagery data: in five data sets, our algorithms could reconstruct and predict with significant accuracy a pattern imagined by the subjects.

http://www.unicog.org/publications/ThirionDehaene_InverseRetinotopy_Neuroimage2006.pdf

Reference 3:

“Decoding the visual and subjective contents of the human brain” Yukiyasu Kamitani1 & Frank Tong

Nature Neuroscience 8, 679 - 685 (2005) 

Abstract The potential for human neuroimaging to read out the detailed contents of a person's mental state has yet to be fully explored. We investigated whether the perception of edge orientation, a fundamental visual feature, can be decoded from human brain activity measured with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Using statistical algorithms to classify brain states, we found that ensemble fMRI signals in early visual areas could reliably predict on individual trials which of eight stimulus orientations the subject was seeing. Moreover, when subjects had to attend to one of two overlapping orthogonal gratings, feature-based attention strongly biased ensemble activity toward the attended orientation. These results demonstrate that fMRI activity patterns in early visual areas, including primary visual cortex (V1), contain detailed orientation information that can reliably predict subjective perception. Our approach provides a framework for the readout of fine-tuned representations in the human brain and their subjective contents.
results.name: Looking Inside a Person’s Mind

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- What happens in Kangoo club stays in Kangoo club - pls don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- There is no secure place to put your things, open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a healthy snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.
results.name: Kangoo Jumps Workout

Courtesy Posting for :  New England Folk Festival - NEFFA 

The NEFFA Festival (also known as The New England Folk Festival) is a fabulous blend of dance, music, crafts, and food from many lands. The 2016 Festival, our 72nd annual Festival to be held on April 15-17, 2016 in Mansfield, Massachusetts (near Boston).

One of the things that makes the Festival special is that all performers donate their talents as volunteers.

New England Folk Festival - NEFFA

No Meetup Host for this Event - Attend at your own leisure...........

results.name: New England Folk Festival - NEFFA

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

The cost is $10.00 and many people like to pay before coming. if so, you may use PayPal Here: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=D828CV9K4JFV8

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta
results.name: Boston Drum Circle Friday at DrumConnection!

venue.name: Wild Rover Bar Boston - 1 Block from Faneuil Hall

results.description:
Biagio puts on a great party and has graciously invited the members of the Boston Social and Cultural Club.  Biagio rented the whole 2nd floor of the Wild Rover to make this an awesome private party.

PLEASE DO NOT DOUBLE RSVP! ----PLEASE RSVP IN ONE GROUP ONLY!! 

Join the legendary crazy dancing at our Mix +Mingle Meetup Private Party for 120+ members with our own DJ, dance area, 2 bars +apps/food from 7-9PM.

7-9PM is the Social Mixer which the best because it allows you to get to know your fellow Meetup members. After 9PM the crazy dancing + loud music starts so please do not complain, since members come to dance to loud music after 9PM.

Bonus FREE KARAOKE on 1st  floor if you want to kick it KARAOKE style.

Its the party everyone loves since its the starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

The BEST part!...Come between 7 and 8:20PM to get 1 included (FREE) drink ticket good for any beer, wine, or mixed drink! (Sorry no shots or top-shelf liquor). This 1 Drink ticket will expire at 8:20PM sharp!!.....Please don't forget to TIP your bartender for the included drink!

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist band to wear so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

1. Biagio collects $10 cash from everyone, but the invited Larger Meetup Group Head Organizers and some of the  Social Fun Organizers..

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Special Wild Rover Venue Update: Members under age 21 are NOT admitted. They MUST CHECK Valid ID, Driver License or Passports. If you don't present it they can't let you in sorry. NO large luggage or suitcases/boxes allowed in this venue.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Biagio at the top of the stairs.

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist bands to  so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

1. Biagio collects $10 cash from everyone, but the invited Larger Meetup Group Head Organizers and some of the  Social Fun Organizers..

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Special Wild Rover Venue Update: Members under age 21 are NOT admitted. They MUST CHECK Valid ID, Driver License or Passports. If you don't present it they can't let you in sorry. NO large luggage or suitcases/boxes allowed in this venue.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
